A valence-independent rating of the narrator's emotional intensity was added to provide comparability between videos portraying different primary emotions and to explore changes in neural activity related to variations in emotional intensity over time. We also added a new neutral control condition to investigate general emotional processing. In the scanner, 34 healthy participants watched 6 video clips of people talking about an autobiographical event (2 sad, 2 happy and 2 neutral clips) while continuously rating the narrator's emotional intensity. Fluctuation in perceived emotional intensity correlated with activity in brain regions previously implicated in cognitive empathy (bilateral superior temporal sulcus, temporoparietal junction, and temporal pole) and affective empathy (right anterior insula and inferior frontal gyrus). When emotional video clips were compared to neutral video clips, we observed higher activity in similar brain regions. Empathic accuracy, on the other hand, was only positively related to activation in regions that have been implicated in cognitive empathy. Our modified empathic accuracy task provides a new method for studying the underlying components and dynamic processes involved in empathy. While the task elicited both cognitive and affective empathy, successful tracking of others' emotions relied predominantly on the cognitive components of empathy. The fMRI data analysis techniques developed here may prove valuable in characterising the neural basis of empathic difficulties observed across a range of psychiatric conditions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of a social (empathy) task performed in the scanner with 34 healthy participants; reports activation across multiple brain regions (not limited to ROI), indicating whole-brain results. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly; include for full-text review to confirm ages fall within 18–60 and confirm whole-brain analysis details.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used fMRI while healthy adult participants (final sample N=34, ages 20–30) performed a social cognition task (a modified Empathic Accuracy Task assessing empathy/mentalising). Analyses were whole-brain (SPM12 preprocessing, group-level random-effects, TFCE FWE correction) with reported whole-brain clusters and peak activations; no ROI-only reporting. Participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders were excluded. The paper is an original fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and reports results suitable for inclusion in a meta-analysis of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Cooperation and deception recruit different subsets of the theory-of-mind network.
studies.abstract: The term "theory of mind" (ToM) describes an evolved psychological mechanism that is necessary to represent intentions and expectations in social interaction. It is thus involved in determining the proclivity of others to cooperate or defect. While in cooperative settings between two parties the intentions and expectations of the protagonists match, they diverge in deceptive scenarios, in which one protagonist is intentionally manipulated to hold a false belief about the intention of the other. In a functional magnetic resonance imaging paradigm using cartoons showing social interactions (including the outcome of the interaction) between two or three story characters, respectively, we sought to determine those brain areas of the ToM network involved in reasoning about cooperative versus deceptive interactions. Healthy volunteers were asked to reflect upon the protagonists' intentions and expectations in cartoons depicting cooperation, deception or a combination of both, where two characters cooperated to deceive a third. Reasoning about the mental states of the story characters yielded substantial differences in activation patterns: both deception and cooperation activated bilateral temporoparietal junction, parietal and cingulate regions, while deception alone additionally recruited orbitofrontal and medial prefrontal regions. These results indicate an important role for prefrontal cortex in processing a mismatch between a character's intention and another's expectations as required in complex social interactions.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind: cooperation vs deception) performed in healthy volunteers and reports activations across multiple brain regions (suggesting whole‑brain results). No indication of psychiatric/neurological samples or ROI‑only analyses. Abstract does not state participant ages (18–60), so full text should be checked for age eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception, cooperation/deception) with healthy adult participants (n=13; age range 22–38, within 18–60). The task required participants to attribute intentions/beliefs while being scanned. The paper reports exploratory whole-brain random-effects analyses (ToM vs non-ToM) and contrasts between conditions with whole-brain results (thresholds and cluster extent provided), although ROI-based follow-up was also performed. Participants had no neurological or psychiatric disorders. This is an original experimental fMRI study (not a review) and does not report data from clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neural Activity while Imitating Emotional Faces is Related to Both Lower and Higher-Level Social Cognitive Performance.
studies.abstract: Imitation and observation of actions and facial emotional expressions activates the human fronto-parietal mirror network. There is skepticism regarding the role of this low-level network in more complex high-level social behaviour. We sought to test whether neural activation during an observation/imitation task was related to both lower and higher level social cognition. We employed an established observe/imitate task of emotional faces during functional MRI in 28 healthy adults, with final analyses based on 20 individuals following extensive quality control. Partial least squares (PLS) identified patterns of relationships between spatial activation and a battery of objective out-of-scanner assessments that index lower and higher-level social cognitive performance, including the Penn emotion recognition task, reading the mind in the eyes, the awareness of social inference test (TASIT) parts 1, 2, and 3, and the relationships across domains (RAD) test. Strikingly, activity in limbic, right inferior frontal, and inferior parietal areas during imitation of emotional faces correlated with performance on emotion evaluation (TASIT1), social inference - minimal (TASIT2), social inference - enriched (TASIT3), and the RAD tests. These results show a role for this network in both lower-level and higher-level social cognitive processes which are collectively critical for social functioning in everyday life.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Task: fMRI observe/imitate emotional faces — a social-processing task. Participants: healthy adults (28 enrolled, 20 in final analyses). Analysis: whole-brain multivariate PLS identifying spatial activation patterns (not ROI). No psychiatric/neurological sample. Satisfies inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (ages 18–55) performing a social-related task (imitate/observe emotional faces). Participants were screened healthy (SCID, urine tox) and no psychiatric/neurological disorders included. Whole-brain analyses were performed (spatio-temporal PLS across the whole brain with voxel-wise bootstrap ratios and a corroborating whole-brain GLM in SPM8; results presented as whole-brain voxel patterns in MNI space). Not a review/meta-analysis, and not an ROI-only study. All inclusion criteria met and no exclusion criteria violated.

studies.title: Dynamic pupillary exchange engages brain regions encoding social salience.
studies.abstract: Covert exchange of autonomic responses may shape social affective behavior, as observed in mirroring of pupillary responses during sadness processing. We examined how, independent of facial emotional expression, dynamic coherence between one's own and another's pupil size modulates regional brain activity. Fourteen subjects viewed pairs of eye stimuli while undergoing fMRI. Using continuous pupillometry biofeedback, the size of the observed pupils was varied, correlating positively or negatively with changes in participants' own pupils. Viewing both static and dynamic stimuli activated right fusiform gyrus. Observing dynamically changing pupils activated STS and amygdala, regions engaged by non-static and salient facial features. Discordance between observed and observer's pupillary changes enhanced activity within bilateral anterior insula, left amygdala and anterior cingulate. In contrast, processing positively correlated pupils enhanced activity within left frontal operculum. Our findings suggest pupillary signals are monitored continuously during social interactions and that incongruent changes activate brain regions involved in tracking motivational salience and attentionally meaningful information. Naturalistically, dynamic coherence in pupillary change follows fluctuations in ambient light. Correspondingly, in social contexts discordant pupil response is likely to reflect divergence of dispositional state. Our data provide empirical evidence for an autonomically mediated extension of forward models of motor control into social interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study where 14 subjects viewed eye stimuli with dynamic pupillary feedback—a social processing task in healthy adults. Abstract reports activations across multiple brain regions (fusiform, STS, amygdala, insula, ACC), with no ROI or patient-group exclusions. Age range and explicit whole-brain statement not given, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 22) performing a social-related task (viewing eyes and dynamic pupillary feedback to examine social salience). Whole-brain fMRI data were acquired and whole-brain group analyses are reported (main effect of viewing eye stimuli reported at whole-brain corrected threshold), not ROI-only results. Participants were screened for neurological/psychiatric illness and none were reported. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and meets all inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Neural bases of social communicative intentions in speech.
studies.abstract: Our ability to understand others' communicative intentions in speech is key to successful social interaction. Indeed, misunderstanding an 'excuse me' as apology, while meant as criticism, may have important consequences. Recent behavioural studies have provided evidence that prosody, that is, vocal tone, is an important indicator for speakers' intentions. Using a novel audio-morphing paradigm, the present functional magnetic resonance imaging study examined the neurocognitive mechanisms that allow listeners to 'read' speakers' intents from vocal prosodic patterns. Participants categorized prosodic expressions that gradually varied in their acoustics between criticism, doubt, and suggestion. Categorizing typical exemplars of the three intentions induced activations along the ventral auditory stream, complemented by amygdala and mentalizing system. These findings likely depict the stepwise conversion of external perceptual information into abstract prosodic categories and internal social semantic concepts, including the speaker's mental state. Ambiguous tokens, in turn, involved cingulo-opercular areas known to assist decision-making in case of conflicting cues. Auditory and decision-making processes were flexibly coupled with the amygdala, depending on prosodic typicality, indicating enhanced categorization efficiency of overtly relevant, meaningful prosodic signals. Altogether, the results point to a model in which auditory prosodic categorization and socio-inferential conceptualization cooperate to translate perceived vocal tone into a coherent representation of the speaker's intent.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining prosodic decoding of communicative intentions (a social task). Abstract reports whole-brain activations (ventral auditory stream, amygdala, mentalizing system) and does not indicate ROI-only analyses, clinical samples, or that it is a review. Participant health and ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: The study reports a task-based functional MRI experiment where healthy adult participants (N=22; mean age 27.35, all native speakers; no neurological/psychiatric history) performed a social-related task (classification of speakers’ communicative intentions from prosody). Whole-brain analyses are reported (voxel-level threshold P<0.0001 with cluster-level FWE correction P<0.05) rather than ROI-only results. The sample falls within the 18–60 age range and participants were screened for neurological/psychiatric disorders. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it should be included in the review of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

studies.title: Motivation Modulates Brain Networks in Response to Faces Varying in Race and Status: A Multivariate Approach.
studies.abstract: Previous behavioral and neuroimaging work indicates that individuals who are externally motivated to respond without racial prejudice tend not to spontaneously regulate their prejudice and prefer to focus on nonracial attributes when evaluating others. This fMRI multivariate analysis used partial least squares analysis to examine the distributed neural processing of race and a relevant but ostensibly nonracial attribute (i.e., socioeconomic status) as a function of the perceiver's external motivation. Sixty-one white male participants (
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study examining neural responses to faces varying by race and socioeconomic status—clearly a social processing task in healthy adult participants (61 white males). Abstract indicates multivariate whole-brain analysis approach (partial least squares), though exact age range and explicit statement of whole-brain results are not given. Include for full-text review to confirm age criteria (18–60) and that whole-brain results (not ROI-only) are reported.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=60 male participants, mean age 23.8, within 18–60) who performed an explicit social task (impression formation of faces varying in race and socioeconomic status) while being scanned. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (behavioral and task PLS across the whole brain with voxelwise bootstrap ratios and cluster reporting) rather than ROI-only results. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not report data from psychiatric or neurological patient groups. All inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results); no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: The neural bases of social intention understanding: the role of interaction goals.
studies.abstract: Decoding others' intentions is a crucial aspect of social cognition. Neuroimaging studies suggest that inferring immediate goals engages the neural system for action understanding (i.e. mirror system), while the decoding of long-term intentions requires the system subserving the attribution of mental states (i.e. mentalizing). A controversial issue, stimulated by recent inconsistent results, concerns whether the two systems are concurrently vs. exclusively involved in intention understanding. This issue is particularly relevant in the case of social interactions, whose processing has been mostly, but not uncontroversially, associated with the mentalizing system. We tested the alternative hypothesis that the relative contribution of the two systems in intention understanding may also depend on the shared goal of interacting agents. To this purpose, 27 participants observed social interactions differing in their cooperative vs. affective shared goal during functional-Magnetic-Resonance-Imaging. The processing of both types of interactions activated the right temporo-parietal junction involved in mentalizing on action goals. Additionally, whole-brain and regions-of-interest analyses showed that the action understanding system (inferior prefrontal-parietal cortex) was more strongly activated by cooperative interactions, while the mentalizing-proper system (medial prefrontal cortex) was more strongly engaged by affective interactions. These differences were modulated by individual differences in empathizing. Both systems can thus be involved in understanding social intentions, with a relative weighting depending on the specific shared goal of the interaction.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Functional MRI study where participants observed social interactions (social-related task). Reports whole-brain analyses (alongside ROI), and participants (n=27) appear to be healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=27; ages ~24.9–26.3) that examined neural processing of social interactions while participants viewed pictures of cooperative and affective interactions (a social-related task). Imaging used whole-brain analyses (random-effects, whole-brain contrasts, conjunctions) with FWE-corrected thresholds reported; thus whole-brain results are available. Although ROI analyses are also reported, results are not ROI-only. Participants were healthy and within the 18–60 age range, and this is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). No exclusion criteria (clinical samples, ROI-only results, or review) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

studies.title: A neural model of valuation and information virality.
studies.abstract: Information sharing is an integral part of human interaction that serves to build social relationships and affects attitudes and behaviors in individuals and large groups. We present a unifying neurocognitive framework of mechanisms underlying information sharing at scale (virality). We argue that expectations regarding self-related and social consequences of sharing (e.g., in the form of potential for self-enhancement or social approval) are integrated into a domain-general value signal that encodes the value of sharing a piece of information. This value signal translates into population-level virality. In two studies (
studies.journal: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract reports fMRI investigation of social information sharing (a social-related task) in what appears to be healthy adults and does not indicate exclusionary ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. However, the abstract does not specify whether whole-brain results were reported. Insufficient detail to confirm whole-brain reporting, so include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This paper reports two original fMRI experiments in healthy adult participants (study 1 n=41, study 2 n=39; ages 18–24; screened for psychiatric/neurological disorders). Tasks probe social-related processing (sharing decisions, mentalizing-related constructs; a social-processing ROI based on a false-belief localizer) while participants viewed article headlines/abstracts. The authors report both ROI analyses and exploratory whole-brain analyses (cluster- and permutation-corrected whole-brain maps and tables of clusters associated with population-level virality), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain results. This is not a review/meta-analysis and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

studies.title: Neural Mechanisms Underlying Individual Differences in Control-Averse Behavior.
studies.abstract: When another person tries to control one's decisions, some people might comply, but many will feel the urge to act against that control. This control aversion can lead to suboptimal decisions and it affects social interactions in many societal domains. To date, however, it has been unclear what drives individual differences in control-averse behavior. Here, we address this issue by measuring brain activity with fMRI while healthy female and male human participants made choices that were either free or controlled by another person, with real consequences to both interaction partners. In addition, we assessed the participants' affects, social cognitions, and motivations via self-reports. Our results indicate that the social cognitions perceived distrust and lack of understanding for the other person play a key role in explaining control aversion at the behavioral level. At the neural level, we find that control-averse behavior can be explained by functional connectivity between the inferior parietal lobule and the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, brain regions commonly associated with attention reorientation and cognitive control. Further analyses reveal that the individual strength of functional connectivity complements and partially mediates the self-reported social cognitions in explaining individual differences in control-averse behavior. These findings therefore provide valuable contributions to a more comprehensive model of control aversion.
studies.journal: The Journal of neuroscience : the official journal of the Society for Neuroscience
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI was used while healthy adult participants made social-interaction decisions (free vs controlled by another person). Participants are healthy adults; study reports whole-brain functional connectivity findings rather than ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria met.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study used task-based fMRI while participants performed a social decision-making task (control aversion task involving choices influenced by another person), meeting the social-related task requirement. Participants were healthy young adults (n=51 after exclusions, mean age 22, screened for psychiatric/neurological disorders), meeting the healthy 18–60 criterion. Analyses were whole-brain (random-effects, whole-brain cluster-level FWE correction reported) and results are not limited to ROI-only approaches. The paper is original empirical fMRI research (not a review) and does not include clinical patients. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Autism spectrum traits predict the neural response to eye gaze in typical individuals.
studies.abstract: Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are neurodevelopmental disorders characterised by impaired social interaction and communication, restricted interests and repetitive behaviours. The severity of these characteristics are posited to lie on a continuum extending into the typical population, and typical adults' performance on behavioural tasks that are impaired in ASD is correlated with the extent to which they display autistic traits (as measured by Autism Spectrum Quotient, AQ). Individuals with ASD also show structural and functional differences in brain regions involved in social perception. Here we show that variation in AQ in typically developing individuals is associated with altered brain activity in the neural circuit for social attention perception while viewing others' eye gaze. In an fMRI experiment, participants viewed faces looking at variable or constant directions. In control conditions, only the eye region was presented or the heads were shown with eyes closed but oriented at variable or constant directions. The response to faces with variable vs. constant eye gaze direction was associated with AQ scores in a number of regions (posterior superior temporal sulcus, intraparietal sulcus, temporoparietal junction, amygdala, and MT/V5) of the brain network for social attention perception. No such effect was observed for heads with eyes closed or when only the eyes were presented. The results demonstrate a relationship between neurophysiology and autism spectrum traits in the typical (non-ASD) population and suggest that changes in the functioning of the neural circuit for social attention perception is associated with an extended autism spectrum in the typical population.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: fMRI study of social perception (eye gaze) in typically developing adults; reports neural responses across multiple whole-brain regions (pSTS, IPS, TPJ, amygdala, MT/V5). Participants are non‑ASD typical adults. Abstract indicates whole‑brain findings rather than ROI-only analyses and does not involve clinical populations. Thus meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 18–30) performing a social-related task (gaze perception/mentalizing). The authors report whole-brain second-level analyses (AQ regressor) with whole-brain FDR-corrected results (p<0.05) identifying clusters in pSTS, TPJ, amygdala, IPS, etc. Participants with neurological/psychiatric disorders were excluded. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Although supplementary ROI analyses are reported, the primary inferential statistics reported are whole-brain analyses, so the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Regional brain responses in nulliparous women to emotional infant stimuli.
studies.abstract: Infant cries and facial expressions influence social interactions and elicit caretaking behaviors from adults. Recent neuroimaging studies suggest that neural responses to infant stimuli involve brain regions that process rewards. However, these studies have yet to investigate individual differences in tendencies to engage or withdraw from motivationally relevant stimuli. To investigate this, we used event-related fMRI to scan 17 nulliparous women. Participants were presented with novel infant cries of two distress levels (low and high) and unknown infant faces of varying affect (happy, sad, and neutral) in a randomized, counter-balanced order. Brain activation was subsequently correlated with scores on the Behavioral Inhibition System/Behavioral Activation System scale. Infant cries activated bilateral superior and middle temporal gyri (STG and MTG) and precentral and postcentral gyri. Activation was greater in bilateral temporal cortices for low- relative to high-distress cries. Happy relative to neutral faces activated the ventral striatum, caudate, ventromedial prefrontal, and orbitofrontal cortices. Sad versus neutral faces activated the precuneus, cuneus, and posterior cingulate cortex, and behavioral activation drive correlated with occipital cortical activations in this contrast. Behavioral inhibition correlated with activation in the right STG for high- and low-distress cries relative to pink noise. Behavioral drive correlated inversely with putamen, caudate, and thalamic activations for the comparison of high-distress cries to pink noise. Reward-responsiveness correlated with activation in the left precentral gyrus during the perception of low-distress cries relative to pink noise. Our findings indicate that infant cry stimuli elicit activations in areas implicated in auditory processing and social cognition. Happy infant faces may be encoded as rewarding, whereas sad faces activate regions associated with empathic processing. Differences in motivational tendencies may modulate neural responses to infant cues.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Event-related fMRI of emotional infant cries and faces in healthy nulliparous women constituting a social-processing task; whole-brain activations reported across multiple regions. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 and health criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study meets all inclusion criteria: it used functional MRI while participants (healthy, nulliparous adults ages 19–29) completed social-related tasks (viewing infant faces of varying affect and listening to infant cries), and participants were screened as healthy with no psychiatric/neurological disorders. The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects analyses with family-wise error correction and cluster thresholds (i.e., not limited to ROI analyses). It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and the participant age range falls within 18–60. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

studies.title: Oxytocin Facilitates Approach Behavior to Positive Social Stimuli via Decreasing Anterior Insula Activity.
studies.abstract: The neuropeptide oxytocin can extensively modulate human social behavior and affective processing, and its effects can be interpreted in terms of mediating approach-avoidance motivational processes. However, little is known about how oxytocin mediates approach-avoidance behavior and particularly the underlying neural mechanisms.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Abstract implies neural mechanisms of oxytocin but does not specify use of fMRI, participant ages/health, or whole-brain analyses. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Concrete versus abstract forms of social concept: an fMRI comparison of knowledge about people versus social terms.
studies.abstract: The anterior temporal lobes (ATLs) play a key role in conceptual knowledge representation. The hub-and-spoke theory suggests that the contribution of the ATLs to semantic representation is (a) transmodal, i.e. integrating information from multiple sensorimotor and verbal modalities, and (b) pan-categorical, representing concepts from all categories. Another literature, however, suggests that this region's responses are modality- and category-selective; prominent examples include category selectivity for socially relevant concepts and face recognition. The predictions of each approach have never been directly compared. We used data from three studies to compare category-selective responses within the ATLs. Study 1 compared ATL responses to famous people versus another conceptual category (landmarks) from visual versus auditory inputs. Study 2 compared ATL responses to famous people from pictorial and written word inputs. Study 3 compared ATL responses to a different kind of socially relevant stimuli, namely abstract non-person-related words, in order to ascertain whether ATL subregions are engaged for social concepts more generally or only for person-related knowledge. Across all three studies a dominant bilateral ventral ATL cluster responded to
studies.journal: Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences

This is a review discussing resting-state fMRI findings in individuals with autism spectrum disorder and attempts at neurofeedback; it is not an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults, involves a clinical population (ASD), and does not report whole-brain task results. Therefore it meets exclusion criteria.

fMRI study of a dyadic social interaction task in human subjects reporting effects of intranasal oxytocin on functional connectivity across neural networks (whole-brain). Appears to involve healthy adult men and women, not a clinical sample, and is original research rather than an ROI-only analysis or review. Insufficient explicit age range reported, so moderate confidence.
Study focuses on individuals with psychopathy (a psychiatric disorder), not healthy adults; therefore population does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI data during a social-influence/reward decision-making task with groups, likely involving healthy adult participants. However, the abstract does not specify whether results are whole-brain or ROI-only. Because this is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine whole-brain analyses and confirm participant health/age.

Abstract describes a methodological/review article about hyperscanning techniques (EEG, fMRI, fNIRS) and future directions; it does not report an original fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social task or present whole-brain results. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a meta-analysis comparing ASD and schizophrenia neural correlates of social cognition rather than a primary fMRI study of healthy adults. It therefore meets exclusion criteria for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and reports results in clinical populations (ASD, SZ), not healthy participants.

This article is a narrative overview of a research program (a review/synthesis), not a single primary fMRI study. It discusses work in children and individuals with autism (clinical populations) and does not report clear whole-brain results limited to healthy adults aged 18–60. Meets exclusion criteria (review/article summarizing multiple studies and includes clinical/developmental samples).

Abstract reports study of neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in healthy young adults, matching the review focus. However it does not explicitly state use of fMRI or whole-brain results; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and whole-brain analyses.

fMRI during a social task (Cyberball) in healthy undergraduates; reports whole-brain activations (ACC, DLPFC) rather than ROI-only; participants are non-clinical (range of social anxiety scores, not diagnosed disorders); meets objective of social processing in healthy adults.

Study includes participants with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder and reports results involving this clinical group. Exclusion criteria rule out studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although healthy controls are included, the presence of a clinical sample and group comparisons means it does not meet the "healthy participants only" criterion.

Abstract describes an fMRI valence classification task probing social-cognition dimensions (agency and communion) and reports distributed brain activations/deactivations (suggesting whole-brain analyses). Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so full text needed to confirm healthy adults aged 18–60. Include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

This is a narrative review of semantic dementia (neuroimaging, pathology, genetics), not an original fMRI study. It is a review article (not primary data), likely includes patient populations with semantic dementia, and does not report whole-brain fMRI results in healthy adults performing a social task. Meets exclusion criterion for reviews.

This article is a narrative review of PFC function in social cognition/moral judgment rather than a primary fMRI study reporting original whole-brain results in healthy adult participants; it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

This is a selective review (not an original fMRI study) summarizing literature on postpartum psychopathology and maternal caregiving, including clinical groups (postpartum depression, substance-using mothers). It does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adults performing a social task or whole-brain results. Therefore it meets exclusion criteria.

This study is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies and also reports lesion patient data; exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses and studies reporting results in participants with neurological disorders. The abstract does not present a primary fMRI study of healthy adults with whole-brain results.

fMRI study of social vs nonsocial gesture processing in (presumably) healthy adults; abstract reports whole-brain activation patterns (bilateral thalamus, frontal operculum, insula, putamen, amygdala). Not an ROI-only analysis or review. Age not specified, but no clinical sample noted, so include for full-text review.

This is a review and case report on deep brain stimulation for severe autism patients, not a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults. Participants have a neurodevelopmental disorder (autism), and no whole-brain fMRI social-processing results are reported. Meets exclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during live social exchanges (reciprocal imitation of hand gestures), meeting the social-task criterion. Participant health/age and whether whole-brain results were reported are not specified. No indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Includes participants with Autism Spectrum Disorder (a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental disorder). Exclusion criterion 'studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders' is clearly met, so the study must be excluded despite using fMRI on a social task and including healthy controls.

This article is a meta-analysis/systematic review, not an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks; exclusion criteria specify excluding meta-analyses. Abstract lacks primary whole-brain fMRI data on participants.

This article is a narrative review of adolescent social cognitive development and fMRI findings, not an original fMRI study reporting whole-brain results in healthy adult participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and lacks primary empirical fMRI data for inclusion.

fMRI study investigating social-interactive processing (live vs recorded speech) in human participants; addresses social cognition. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status nor explicitly state whole-brain versus ROI-only results (mentions functional localizer), so insufficient information to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and presence of whole-brain results.

Resting-state fMRI study of children including ASD patients and typically developing controls—not task-based social processing in healthy adults. Includes participants with a neurodevelopmental disorder and focuses on clinical group differences, so does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study examines neural and behavioral theory-of-mind deficits in patients with first-episode schizophrenia — a clinical population. Does not involve healthy adults, thus fails the ‘healthy participants’ inclusion criterion.

This article is a voxel-based meta-analysis (systematic meta-analysis of fMRI studies), not an original fMRI study in participants. Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses should be excluded.

fMRI study of dynamic facial expression perception (social task) with a relatively large sample (n=51) of presumably healthy adults; reports widespread whole-brain activations (cortical and limbic regions). Not an ROI study, not a review, and no clinical population reported.

fMRI study (N=34) where participants observed social integrity threats and reported schadenfreude or fremdscham—clearly a social task. Abstract reports activation of left anterior insula and nucleus accumbens and connectivity, implying whole-brain functional results rather than ROI-only. Participant health appears to be typical adults, but exact ages (18–60) and explicit whole-brain statement are not provided in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study reports results from participants with schizophrenia and clinical high-risk (attenuated psychosis), violating the exclusion criterion excluding psychiatric populations. Additionally, it’s unclear whether the task was social-related or fMRI-based, but the presence of clinical participants is sufficient for exclusion.

fMRI study examining self-referential and social stimulus processing with reported whole-brain activations and no indication of clinical/neurological populations. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other methodological details.

fMRI study of social signal detection in healthy participants performing social tasks; abstract reports whole-brain activations (pMTG, pSTS, mPFC, temporal pole, striatum). No evidence of clinical sample or ROI-only analyses; fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports event-related fMRI during a social (face) versus non-social task and describes whole-brain activation patterns, meeting key objectives. However participant health status and ages (18–60) are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion should be confirmed at full-text review.

This article is a multimodal coordinate-based meta-analysis of first-degree relatives of schizophrenia patients, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It is a meta-analysis (explicitly excluded) and does not clearly report task-based whole-brain fMRI results in healthy 18–60 adults.

fMRI study in 38 participants performing a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss) reporting activation in ventral striatum and precuneus, indicating whole-brain social-reward findings. No psychiatric/neurological disorders reported and not an ROI-only analysis. Fits the review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

This is a narrative/review article focused on schizophrenia and negative symptoms; it discusses fMRI findings in patient populations rather than reporting original fMRI data from healthy adults. It is therefore a review involving psychiatric participants and not eligible for inclusion.

This is a review chapter of oxytocin effects in individuals with ASD rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It summarizes neuroimaging and behavioral findings in ASD (a clinical population) and is a review, meeting exclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social working memory (a social task) with neural activation findings relevant to social cognition. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status/ages or explicitly confirm whole-brain (versus ROI) analyses. Because key inclusion details are insufficient in the abstract, include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI protocol including social perception and reasoning tasks in a sample of 78 participants, with whole-brain group and individual analyses (not ROI-only). However, the abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm health status, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.
Participants are adolescents (ages 14–18), not adults within the required 18–60 age range for inclusion; therefore the study does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study using a gambling task to examine understanding others' regret (social cognition). Reports activation of vmPFC, ACC and hippocampus, implying whole-brain results; no indication of clinical sample. Abstract lacks ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain reporting.

This is a mini-review (not an original fMRI study) summarizing MRI findings related to OXTR and autism; it does not report primary whole-brain fMRI results in healthy adults performing a social task and includes ASD populations. Exclude.

Resting-state (task-free) fMRI study in a sample including individuals with autism; not a task-based social processing experiment and includes participants with a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental disorder. Does not meet inclusion criteria of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Study examines participants with early-course schizophrenia (clinical sample), not healthy adults. This violates the exclusion criterion excluding studies with psychiatric disorders. Abstract thus does not meet inclusion for healthy adult social fMRI.

This is a review/theoretical article summarizing neuroimaging literature on cerebellar function, not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It does not report primary whole-brain fMRI results and is effectively a review (excluded per criteria).

fMRI study comparing social vs non-social (collaborative vs solitary) tasks during learning and recognition; reports whole-brain activations in medial prefrontal and cingulate cortices. No psychiatric/neurological patient population indicated. Age range not specified in abstract, so moderate confidence; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain analysis methods.

Participants are children in middle childhood (roughly ages 7–13), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Thus the population does not meet the review’s adult inclusion criterion. Abstract gives no indication of adult participants.

This is an essay/review arguing for cross-species social neuroscience, not an empirical fMRI study. The abstract reports no fMRI methods, participant sample, or whole-brain results, so it fails inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in children (ages 7–12) including autism spectrum disorder participants; not a task-based social processing study and participants are not healthy adults (18–60). Therefore ineligible.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social emotion-inference task with feedback. The abstract implies healthy adult perceivers and reports brain activity in ventral striatum, vmPFC, and TPJ consistent with whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only analyses, clinical sample, or review) are evident. Abstract provides sufficient basis for inclusion for full-text review.

Participants are early adolescents (ages 10.5–13.4), not adults 18–60, and the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based fMRI during social processing. Does not meet age or task-based fMRI inclusion criteria.

Study investigates PTSD patients (clinical population). Inclusion requires healthy adults; exclusion criterion forbids studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Abstract clearly indicates PTSD sample, so exclude.

Abstract indicates this is a review discussing neuroimaging and behavioral studies (not an original fMRI experiment). Excluded as a review/meta-analysis rather than a primary fMRI study of healthy adults.

This is a narrative review focusing on adolescent social-brain development rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It discusses structural and functional findings in adolescence (not adults 18–60) and is a review/speculative paper, so does not present whole-brain fMRI results from healthy adult participants.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants made self-descriptiveness judgments (a social/self-processing task); reports neural activations across networks (whole-brain findings implied); no evidence of patient sample or ROI-only analyses.

The abstract describes a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies (neuroimaging of love) rather than an original fMRI study with participants. Per exclusion criteria (‘systematic reviews or meta-analyses’), exclude. Abstract also lacks primary participant/whole-brain result details.

fMRI in healthy adult participants examining amygdala response to fear-inducing stimuli with a social cognition framing. Abstract does not specify that the task is explicitly social nor whether results are whole-brain versus ROI, so information is insufficient to determine eligibility from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify task socialness and whole-brain reporting.

Whole-brain fMRI study of retaliation (a social interaction/provocation task) in healthy volunteers; group whole-brain analyses reported, not ROI-only, and participants appear to be healthy adults. No indication of psychiatric/neurological disorder. Age range not specified in abstract but likely adults; include for full-text review.

Dual-fMRI hyperscanning during a social interaction task; reports whole-brain activations in social-cognition and motor regions. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages (18–60). Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and whole-brain analyses.

Two fMRI experiments investigating understanding of intentions in social interaction (social processing) in presumably healthy adult participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages or whether analyses were whole-brain vs ROI; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with participants viewing social stimuli (love and power movie clips) — meets social-task and fMRI criteria. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state ‘healthy’, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This article is a large-scale meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study of healthy adult participants. Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded. The abstract does not report new whole-brain fMRI data from healthy adults completing social tasks.

The study reports fMRI results from participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental condition). Although it includes control subjects and uses a social task, inclusion of a clinical population meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders.

Study reports results in individuals with autism spectrum conditions (clinical population), not healthy adults. Also uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm required by inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating communicative (social) actions; reports whole-brain activation patterns across cortical areas and does not mention ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Participant age/health not specified in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age 18–60, healthy).

fMRI study using a social working-memory task manipulating social load; reports whole-brain networks (medial and lateral frontoparietal) showing load-dependent activity and links to individual differences in trait perspective-taking. No mention of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

The study sample consists of adolescents (n=63), not adults age 18–60 required by the review. Additionally, the fMRI task used was the Monetary Incentive Delay reward task (non-social), so it does not clearly assess social-related processing. Therefore it does not meet key inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports region-of-interest (ROI) analyses and includes participants with a psychiatric disorder (manic patients). Inclusion criteria require healthy adult participants and exclusion of studies reporting results among psychiatric samples or using only ROI analyses; thus exclude.

Abstract reports an fMRI study in healthy adults performing social-related tasks (attributing emotions to humans/animals) and describes neural activations beyond ROI-level findings. No clinical population is indicated. Age range and explicit whole-brain reporting are not stated, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study includes participants with Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY), a clinical/genetic condition, and reports group comparisons between XXY patients and controls. This does not meet the ‘healthy participants’ inclusion criterion, so it should be excluded.

Abstract reports results for individuals with high-functioning autism (a neurodevelopmental/clinical population). The review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric or neurological disorders. Although fMRI social tasks and whole-brain contrasts are present, inclusion of a clinical group warrants exclusion.

This is a review article focusing on early brain maturation in infants/perinatal populations rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults. It is a review (not primary task-based fMRI data) and does not report whole-brain results in healthy 18–60-year-olds.
Study includes participants with fragile X syndrome (a neurodevelopmental disorder); thus it reports results in a clinical population, violating the healthy participants inclusion criterion.

This study is an fMRI Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis, not a primary fMRI study with human participants performing tasks. Per exclusion criteria, systematic reviews/meta-analyses are excluded.

The study used resting-state fMRI to assess connectivity changes after rTMS rather than an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although participants are healthy adults, no task-based social processing is reported, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study directly investigates social interaction (gaze and socially relevant facial expressions) and reports activations across multiple brain regions, consistent with whole-brain results. No indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adults, so insufficient demographic detail—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study includes schizophrenia patients (clinical sample). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although it includes healthy controls and uses a whole-brain fMRI empathy task, presence of clinical participants warrants exclusion.

Participants are clinical groups (Klinefelter syndrome and ASD) and are aged 10–18 (minors), not healthy adults 18–60. This violates inclusion criteria (healthy adults) and meets exclusion criterion (participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders).

Abstract reports results from adults with ADHD (a psychiatric disorder) alongside neurotypical controls. Inclusion requires healthy participants only; exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Therefore exclude.

Task-based fMRI using a social cognition (ToM/empathy) task in subjects classified by social anhedonia; analyses use whole-brain/network methods (ICA, MSAA) rather than ROI-only; appears to be in nonclinical/healthy participants. Meets social processing task and whole-brain criteria.
Participants are schizophrenia patients (psychiatric disorder), not healthy adults; exclusion criterion 'participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders' is clearly met.

fMRI study of live face-to-face social interaction reporting whole-brain activations in social cognition and reward regions. Population likely healthy adults; age not specified in abstract. No ROI-only analyses or reviews. Insufficient age detail—include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 criterion.
Participants are adolescents (mean age 17), below the required adult age range (18-60), so the study population does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a review article summarizing neuroimaging studies in major depressive disorder (clinical population), not a primary fMRI study in healthy adults. It therefore meets exclusion criteria (systematic review and studies of psychiatric participants).

fMRI study of social-related processing (viewing emotional vs neutral social scenes) reporting whole-brain activations (vmPFC, vlPFC, STS, medial PFC). No psychiatric/neurological patient sample or ROI-only analysis mentioned. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social hierarchy processing in an interactive social task with reported neural activations (dLPFC, amygdala, mPFC), indicating relevant social processing. However, participant ages/health status and explicit whole-brain (vs ROI) analysis are not specified. Insufficient detail to exclude; include for full-text review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study including participants with autism spectrum disorders (clinical population) and controls, not a task-based social-processing fMRI in healthy adults. It therefore fails inclusion (task-based in healthy adults) and meets exclusion (clinical population) criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a social-related task, so it does not meet the requirement of participants completing a social task during scanning. Additionally, the sample spans the lifespan (not restricted to ages 18–60). Abstract provides no evidence of task-based whole-brain results.

Resting-state fMRI study including patients with schizophrenia (clinical sample) and healthy controls; not a task-based social-processing fMRI in healthy adults. Fails inclusion criteria (social task, healthy-only participants).

Study uses fMRI during processing of emotional faces (social-related task) in presumably healthy adults; abstract does not specify participant ages or clearly state whole-brain results vs ROI-only. Insufficient detail — include for full-text review.

Study reports results from participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion 'studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders' is met, despite inclusion of healthy controls and social fMRI task.

Resting-state fMRI in an adolescent sample (ages 14–26) rather than a task-based social processing study in adults. Inclusion requires task fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults (18–60); this study does not meet that criterion (no social task, includes minors).

Abstract reports social-cognitive fMRI tasks with reported brain activity (superior temporal sulcus) but does not specify participants’ ages/health status or whether results are whole-brain versus ROI. Insufficient info to determine eligibility—include for full-text review to verify sample and analysis scope.

Abstract reports results from a group of currently depressed mothers (n=14) as well as healthy controls; it therefore includes and reports findings among participants with a psychiatric disorder, which meets the exclusion criteria.

fMRI study using social (traffic-awareness) videos—meets social task and fMRI criteria. Participants appear to be adult drivers with/without offenses and no disorders reported. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60) or whether results are whole-brain versus ROI-only (they state they 'focused' on STS/STG), so information is insufficient to determine exclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and whole-brain reporting.

Participants are children (including an autism spectrum disorder group), not healthy adults 18–60; the study examines language network connectivity rather than social processing; it reports results from a clinical population (ASD). These clearly meet exclusion criteria.

The study reports results from participants with anorexia nervosa (a psychiatric disorder). The exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among psychiatric/neurological patients, so it must be excluded despite including healthy controls.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task); inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task. Although participants are healthy adults, absence of task-based social processing disqualifies it.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social task), includes adolescents (mean age ~14.6) rather than adults 18–60, and reports results in a clinical ASD sample. Fails key inclusion criteria (task-based, healthy adult participants).

fMRI study of empathy (social task) in 30 healthy adult participants; reports whole-brain activation (pain-related areas, fusiform, amygdala, hippocampus, pallidum), not limited to ROI; no psychiatric/neurological patient sample. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes fMRI of dyadic eye-contact (a social task) and reports a data-driven neural basis (imitation-empathy and mentalizing networks). However, participant health status and ages and explicit whole-brain reporting are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (18–60) and whole-brain results.

fMRI study using a social-related task (modified Cyberball combining exclusion and performance). Abstract reports whole-brain activation (dACC, anterior insula, precuneus, TPJ, mPFC), no ROI-only analyses or clinical sample mentioned. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 healthy criteria.

fMRI study using a social task (modified prisoner's dilemma) with 20 participants; whole-brain activations and connectivity reported (rTPJ, pMPFC, hippocampus). No indication of clinical sample or ROI-only analyses. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and whole-brain reporting.

Although this is an fMRI study of social-affective processing with healthy controls, the sample explicitly includes schizophrenia patients and reports results for that clinical group. The review exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so this study should be excluded based on the abstract.
Resting-state fMRI (no social task) and sample includes patients with schizophrenia; not limited to healthy adults performing a social-related task. Meets exclusion criteria.

Participants are patients with behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (a neurological disorder), not healthy adults; exclusion criterion for studies reporting results among participants with neurological disorders is met. Therefore excluded based on abstract alone.

Abstract reports fMRI task probing social attribution/mentalizing in a sample of typically developing adults, meeting the review topic and healthy participants criterion. The abstract does not state whether results are whole-brain vs ROI, so full-text review is needed to confirm whole-brain reporting.

fMRI during a social task (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) in healthy adult participants (female); reports neural activations (ventral striatum, orbitofrontal cortex) rather than an ROI-only focus; no psychiatric/neurological disorders mentioned. Age range not specified—include for full-text review to confirm ages and whole-brain analysis details.

Study used simultaneous EEG-fMRI during a social group categorization/emotional face task in humans, addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health or whether analyses were whole-brain versus ROI, so information is insufficient to rule out inclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and whole-brain results.

fMRI study investigating prosocial learning (social task) in human participants; no indication of psychiatric/neurological samples. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18-60) or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analyses, so include for full-text review to verify these criteria.

fMRI study of social decision-making (public good game) reporting whole-brain activations (mPFC, PCC, pSTS, TPJ) and connectivity. No indication of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses. Participant age/health not stated but likely healthy adults; meets inclusion for full-text review.

Task uses fMRI during reappraisal of angry faces (social processing) in humans. Abstract implies healthy participants and reports whole-brain functional activity/connectivity findings but does not specify ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. Insufficient detail about whole-brain vs ROI and exact sample ages, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study where participants imagined triadic (social) interactions — meets social-related task criterion. Abstract reports whole-brain activations and functional connectivity (mentalizing and mirror networks). No indication of clinical sample; age not specified. Because participant age/health not explicitly stated in abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants (18–21) completed an fMRI social-reward task (feedback about being liked). Sample appears to be healthy individuals varying in social anhedonia (no psychiatric/neurological diagnoses reported). Abstract does not state ROI-only analyses, but whole-brain reporting is not explicit—insufficient detail, so include for full-text review.

Study reports fMRI during a social-related task (vocal emotional processing) in 36 healthy participants and uses whole-brain graph-theoretical analysis with the Power-264 atlas (not ROI-based). Age range not reported in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participants are aged 18–60.

fMRI study of social gaze (a social task) reporting activations in STS and fusiform gyrus, implying whole-brain results. Participants appear to be healthy adults (no clinical population mentioned). No ROI-only analysis or review article. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI comparing MDD patients and healthy controls (clinical sample). Not a task-based social processing study and includes psychiatric participants, violating inclusion and meeting exclusion criteria.

This is a methodological tutorial/review of intersubject correlation rather than an original fMRI study reporting data from healthy adult participants performing a social task; abstract lacks participant/task/whole-brain results and fits exclusion for reviews/meta-analyses.

The study investigates face-processing networks in people with temporal lobe epilepsy (a neurological disorder), so participants are not healthy adults. This meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting results among participants with neurological disorders; thus excluded.

fMRI study investigating neural activity during reflection of one’s own and a friend’s attributes (social cognition) in healthy adult males; reports whole-brain activations and connectivity across several regions. No indication of patient sample or ROI-only analysis. Age range not specified but participants described as adults—include for full-text confirmation.

Participants were patients diagnosed with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder (clinical population). Review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders; thus the study is not eligible despite using fMRI and a social (ToM) task with whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study of live reciprocal social interaction (human-human vs human-robot) with n=21 healthy participants and contrasts reporting increased activation in TPJ, hypothalamus, and amygdala, indicating whole-brain results. No psychiatric/neurological disorders reported. Age range not specified in abstract—confirm in full text.

Study examines individuals with schizophrenia; exclusion criterion prohibits studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Abstract does not indicate healthy adult sample; therefore excluded.

Parametric fMRI study where participants evaluated political belief statements — a social cognition task. Abstract reports whole-brain activation patterns (mPFC, TPJ, DLPFC, ventral striatum, PCC). No ROI-only analyses, patient populations, or review. Participant age/health not specified; include for full-text verification.

Abstract describes an fMRI study (N=178) examining neural networks of empathy and mentalizing during social processing in (presumably) healthy adults; no indication of clinical sample or that only ROI analyses were used. The abstract lacks explicit ages and whole-brain reporting, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Participants are older adults (mean age 79), outside the required 18–60 age range. Although the study used fMRI of empathy, the age criterion alone excludes it from this review.

Study focuses on neural connectivity in Autism Spectrum Disorder (clinical population) rather than healthy adults, and describes functional connectivity of networks (likely resting-state) rather than fMRI during a social-related task. Thus it does not meet the healthy-participant and task-based inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants encoded facts about unfamiliar people (a social-related task). No indication of clinical populations (presumed healthy adults). Abstract reports conjunction analyses and effects in other brain regions, implying whole-brain results rather than ROI-only reporting. Include for full-text review to confirm age range and analytic details.

The abstract describes a narrative review of fMRI literature and a heuristic model in autism rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It focuses on autism (clinical population) and is a review article—meeting exclusion criteria for reviews and studies of clinical participants; no primary whole-brain fMRI results in healthy 18–60 participants are reported.

fMRI study in healthy participants examining spontaneous imitation—a social process. Reports cortical areas with positive correlations and functional connectivity (whole-brain style reporting). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age 18–60) and whole-brain analysis details.

Participants are children with pediatric stroke (neurological disorder), not healthy adults; study uses resting-state connectivity rather than task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria (healthy adults, task fMRI).

fMRI study of a social interaction task (human–human competition requiring Theory of Mind), reports whole-brain activations across multiple regions, and participants described as healthy. Abstract does not report participant ages (18–60 unclear). No exclusion criteria clearly met; include for full-text review to confirm age range and methods.

fMRI study of attractiveness comparisons (social processing) in human participants; not a review and no patient population reported. Age range and explicit whole-brain vs ROI analyses are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study includes and reports results from participants with borderline personality disorder (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so the study should be excluded despite using fMRI social tasks with healthy controls.

fMRI study in healthy human participants performing an animacy-perception task, which is a form of social-related processing; authors report whole-brain analyses. Age/health not explicitly stated in abstract — include for full-text screening to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study investigating social preference learning (participants viewed others’ choices), a social cognitive task in healthy adults; not a review and no indication it’s ROI-only or clinical. Abstract implies whole-brain activation (reports activity in brain areas). Some details (exact ages, explicit statement of whole-brain analysis) are not provided, so include for full-text review.
Participants are non-human (dogs). The review requires fMRI studies in healthy human adults (18–60); this study involves animals and therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract refers specifically to individuals with schizophrenia and people with depression, indicating the study reports results from psychiatric patient groups. This violates the exclusion criterion disallowing studies reporting participants with psychiatric disorders. The abstract lacks evidence that the sample consists solely of healthy adults.

Abstract focuses on ERP (event-related potentials) and theory of emotion development/plasticity rather than reporting an fMRI study. No indication of an fMRI scan during a social task, no participant details, and appears to be a review/theoretical paper. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Includes participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Presence of a patient group in the study therefore warrants exclusion despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Study used fMRI during a Cyberball social exclusion task (meets social-related task). Participants appear to be healthy adults with no psychiatric/neurological sample reported. The abstract does not specify age range or explicitly state whole-brain analyses. Include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and that whole-brain (not ROI-only) results were reported.

The study reports results from participants with a psychiatric disorder (women in recovery from anorexia nervosa) rather than only healthy adults. Because it includes and reports findings for a clinical group, it meets exclusion criteria.

Abstract reports event-related fMRI of a social resource-conflict task with human partners and appears to use whole-brain analysis, but does not specify participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain reporting. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.
Participants are infants (3–7 months), not healthy adults 18–60. The study therefore does not meet the age criterion for inclusion in the review.

fMRI study investigating neural response to social exclusion (a social task) in 21 healthy volunteers; reports whole-brain findings (dorsal ACC and middle frontal gyrus). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 criterion and to verify full-brain analytic approach.

fMRI study where participants read social vs non-social literary passages and social-cognitive performance was measured; reports neural subnetworks (whole-brain patterns) and no indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Age range not specified but participants appear to be healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm demographics and whole-brain reporting.

fMRI study where participants performed a social interaction discrimination task; includes a healthy adult group (ages 20–41) and reports whole-brain activation patterns rather than ROI-only results. Include for full-text review to extract adult-specific whole-brain data.

Study reports fMRI during a social cognition/mentalizing task in healthy adults and addresses review objective. Abstract confirms healthy participants and task-related brain responses. However, it does not specify participant ages (18-60) nor explicitly state whole-brain results, so insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

Abstract describes fMRI in pre- and post-treatment depression — participants are individuals with a psychiatric disorder (depression), not healthy adults. This directly meets an exclusion criterion (studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders).

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=35) performed a social-related task (recall of relationship episodes). Abstract reports whole-brain activation across multiple regions (memory, self, affective areas). Not an ROI-only analysis, not a review, and participants are healthy. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Participants are high-functioning youth with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population) and typically-developing youth—not healthy adults age 18–60. Study therefore does not meet the criterion of healthy adult participants and includes a psychiatric/neurological disorder group, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study of social-related processing (self-, mother-referential tasks and a social attribution/theory-of-mind task) with reported whole-brain group and conjunction analyses. No evidence of clinical populations or ROI-only reporting. Participant ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm 18–60 and health status.

fMRI study where healthy participants performed an emotion-related task (tracing emotion in vocalizations/music), reporting activation across multiple whole-brain regions (e.g., temporal cortex, medial frontal, ACC). No indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm ages and whole-brain reporting.

Study includes participants with first-episode schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Inclusion requires healthy participants; abstracts reporting results among psychiatric populations meet exclusion criteria. Although controls were included and task is social fMRI, presence of patient group warrants exclusion based on abstract alone.

fMRI study examining perception of social interactions in presumably healthy adult participants using point-light figures and moving shapes. Abstract does not specify participant ages or clearly state whole-brain results (some language suggests ROI/localization), so insufficient to determine inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analysis and age range.

This appears to be a review/perspective describing fMRI methods and discussing findings (including developmental/child-focused topics), not a primary fMRI study reporting whole-brain results in healthy adults 18–60; participant/task details are insufficient.

fMRI experiment with participants performing mentalising (social cognition) tasks; abstract reports recruitment of multiple brain regions (insula, posterior STS, temporal pole, cerebellum), implying whole-brain results. No indication of clinical/sample with disorders or ROI-only analyses. Age range not specified—confirm in full text.

fMRI study in healthy adults (n=15) performing a social task (viewing and rating social interactions), meeting the review objective. Abstract does not report participant ages or specify whether results are whole‑brain versus ROI analyses, so insufficient information to confirm full eligibility; include for full‑text review.
Study uses a simple motor task, not social processing, and includes participants with autism (a neurological/psychiatric disorder). These clearly violate the review’s inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition (mentalizing/inferring others' preferences) with whole-brain parametric analyses reported. Participants (n=64) appear to be healthy adults; no psychiatric/neurological disorders mentioned. Age range not specified in abstract but no exclusionary information. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm ages.

Abstract centers on paranoid delusions, implying participants with psychiatric disorder; does not state healthy adult sample. Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Insufficient evidence of healthy participants/whole-brain results.

The study reports fMRI results from two individuals with developmental phonagnosia (a neurological disorder). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders. Although controls are included, the primary subjects are patients, so exclude.

This paper is a quantitative review/meta-analysis of fMRI studies in individuals at clinical high risk for psychosis (clinical population), not primary fMRI data from healthy adults. It is a meta-analysis and includes psychiatric participants, both grounds for exclusion per the criteria.

fMRI task examines social processing (third-party punishment) in lay adult participants; no indication participants had disorders. Abstract reports whole-brain activations but does not specify analysis type or age range; include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain and age criteria.
