Abstract indicates the study includes individuals with autism (clinical group) in addition to unaffected siblings and controls. The review’s exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so this study should be excluded.

The study reports results from schizophrenia patients (psychiatric disorder). Per exclusion criteria, any study reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders must be excluded, even if healthy controls are also included.

fMRI study investigating perception of socially relevant facial expressions (a social-related task) reporting whole-brain FIR analysis and recruitment of extended neural network. Abstract does not indicate clinical/neurological participants or ROI-only analyses. Participant ages/health not specified — insufficient detail to exclude — include for full-text review.

Two fMRI studies in healthy young adults performing a social attribution task (perception of human-like interactions). Reports activation across multiple brain regions (FFA, amygdala, mPFC, STS), implying whole-brain results; no ROI-only analyses or clinical participants reported. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of prosocial (social-related) decision-making in human participants; no indication of psychiatric/neurological disorders or ROI-only analyses. Abstract does not specify participants' ages (18-60) or explicitly state whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants are early adolescents (development during adolescence), not healthy adults aged 18–60 required by the review. Although it uses fMRI during a social task, the sample age clearly falls outside inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and reports results from participants with postpartum major depression (psychiatric disorder). Review requires task-based fMRI in healthy adults aged 18–60, so it fails key inclusion criteria.

fMRI study involving a social task (making listeners laugh) in humans and reports whole-brain activations, but abstract does not specify participant health status/ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social attribution task in a typical (healthy) sample with reported whole-brain activation (TPJ, precuneus, temporal pole). No indication of ROI-only analyses or clinical/neurological disorders. Age range not specified; abstract provides insufficient detail on ages, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers during viewing of empathy-inducing campaign videos (a social cognition task). Abstract reports activation in bilateral STS “among other structures,” indicating whole-brain results rather than ROI-only analyses. Participants described as healthy; no clinical populations. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study using the Ultimatum Game (a social decision-making task) and reports brain activation/connectivity after mindfulness vs control. However, it does not explicitly state participant health status, age range, or confirm whole-brain analyses — include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Participants are children aged 7–10 years, which does not meet the inclusion criterion of healthy adults aged 18–60.

Participants are children aged 7–12 and include individuals diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder. This fails the inclusion criterion of healthy adults aged 18–60 and meets the exclusion criterion of reporting results among participants with a psychiatric/neurological disorder.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of visual short-term memory for emotional (angry) faces—a social processing task in humans. The abstract does not specify participant age/health or whether whole-brain analyses were reported, so information is insufficient to rule out inclusion. Per screening rules, include for full-text review.

fMRI study using an interactive social (reactive aggression) task in healthy human subjects; not a review and not a clinical sample. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages and does not clearly state whole-brain analysis, so full-text review is needed to confirm those inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a novel fMRI-compatible gaze-contingent method and two paradigms involving interactive social stimuli, but does not specify participant health/ages or report whole-brain results. Insufficient information to determine inclusion/exclusion based on abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Abstract explicitly reports a region-of-interest (ROI)-based analysis of amygdala voxels. Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting ROI results; whole-brain results are not clearly reported. Therefore exclude.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional (social) signals and localizes activity in STS, indicating a social-related task in healthy participants. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain versus ROI analyses. Insufficient detail to rule out exclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to confirm health status, age range, and analysis scope.
Participants have Williams syndrome, a genetic/neurodevelopmental disorder; inclusion criterion requires healthy adults. Therefore study must be excluded despite using fMRI social tasks.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social processing (observing social interactions) in human participants and reports activity in DLPFC and posterior STS, with no mention of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses. However, participant ages (18–60) and explicit statement of whole-brain results are not provided, so full text is needed to confirm eligibility.
Study uses resting-state fMRI in adolescent males with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population). Does not involve task-based social processing in healthy adults (age 18-60). Therefore excluded.

Study used fMRI during anticipation/observation of others’ actions (social-related processing). Participants appear to be healthy adult players, but abstract lacks explicit ages and clarity on whole-brain vs ROI-only results. Insufficient information to confirm age range and whole-brain reporting—include for full-text review.

Study includes participants with PTSD (a clinical psychiatric sample). Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so this study is excluded despite inclusion of healthy controls and whole-brain fMRI.

Healthy participants underwent whole-brain fMRI while viewing funny vs non-funny cartoons (humor/social-emotional processing). Whole-brain analysis reported; not an ROI study, not a review, and participants described as healthy. Ages not specified—include for full-text review to confirm 18–60 eligibility and extract details.

Participants are young adults with high-functioning Autism Spectrum Disorder (a neurodevelopmental/psychiatric condition). The review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders, so this study should be excluded despite using fMRI social-processing tasks.

Abstract reports fMRI in obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) patients (clinical population). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Therefore excluded despite relevance of biological-motion (social) task.

Study reports fMRI during an emotional face-viewing task (a social-related task) in healthy men and women and describes whole-brain activity and functional connectivity. The abstract does not indicate ROI-only analyses or clinical populations. Insufficient detail on age range/whole-brain stats, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of mothers viewing emotional expressions of their own children (a social processing task). Participants appear to be healthy adults (mothers); no psychiatric/neurological disorders reported. The abstract does not specify whether results are whole-brain or ROI-only, so information is insufficient to determine exclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analyses and age range.

The study reports fMRI results for participants with Williams syndrome (a genetic neurodevelopmental disorder). The exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Although healthy adult controls are included, presence and reporting of the clinical group warrants exclusion based on the abstract.

fMRI study of social-cognitive processing (promotion/prevention personal goal priming) in adults with reported task-related cortical activation and specific PFC findings, not limited to ROI analyses. No clinical sample indicated. Age range and explicit whole-brain reporting not stated—include for full-text review to confirm.

fMRI study examining agency attribution (social processing) using animated shapes; reports activations across many brain regions consistent with whole-brain results; no mention of clinical populations. Abstract lacks participant ages but does not indicate disorders—include for full-text review to confirm age range and whole-brain analysis details.

Study includes older adults (aging sample) beyond the review age range (18–60). The abstract focuses on age differences and older adults, so participants likely outside the eligible age range; therefore it does not meet the 'healthy participants age 18–60' inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of face identity and eye-gaze—clearly a social processing task in humans and reports distributed brain regions consistent with whole-brain results. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages (18–60). Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and whole-brain analysis details.

Human fMRI study of empathic decision-making (buying for self vs others), addressing social processing in healthy-seeming adults. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analyses, so inclusion should be confirmed at full-text stage.

Participants are adolescents (youth), not adults age 18–60, and the sample includes socially anxious (psychiatric) participants. This clearly violates inclusion criteria (healthy adults 18–60) and meets exclusion criteria (participants with psychiatric disorders).

Event-related fMRI investigating neural responses to faces in relation to political attitudes (a social processing task) in healthy adult participants. Abstract reports whole-brain BOLD signal changes across multiple regions (DLPFC, ACC, insula, anterior temporal poles). No ROI-only analysis or clinical population indicated.

fMRI study examining processing of communicative vs noncommunicative vocalizations, which is a social-related task in humans. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult sample nor whether analyses were whole-brain versus ROI. Include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (18-60) and that results are whole-brain.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social-related processing (vicarious touch/empathy) in presumably healthy adults and links somatosensory (SI) activation to trait empathy. No indication of clinical participants or that only ROI analyses were used. The abstract lacks explicit age range and does not state whole-brain vs ROI reporting, so include for full-text review to confirm these criteria.

Abstract reports functional MRI during a social task (live eye contact) relevant to review. Participant health/ages and whether whole-brain results are reported are not specified in the abstract. No clear exclusion criteria met, so include for full-text review to verify sample (healthy adults 18–60) and whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study using a social-related task (observation of hand actions) in adult participants with and without alexithymia; reports whole-brain activations and brain–behavior correlations. Participants are not described as having psychiatric or neurological disorders. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of charitable donation decisions (a social decision-making task) in human participants with no mention of clinical populations. Abstract lacks explicit participant age range and explicit statement of whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI assessing theory of mind (a social task) in healthy younger and older adults, meeting the primary objective. However, participant age ranges are not specified (older adults may be >60) and it does not state whether whole-brain results were reported versus ROI/network-only analyses. Insufficient detail to determine exclusion, so include for full-text review.

The study explicitly investigates autism spectrum disorder (ASD) participants; inclusion criterion requires healthy participants only. Presence of a clinical group (ASD) meets exclusion criterion 'participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders'. Abstract does not indicate a sample limited to healthy adults.

fMRI study during an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social decision-making task) in adult participants (20 males). Neural correlates reported (recruitment of social brain areas). Abstract does not indicate psychiatric/neurological sample or ROI-only analyses. Whole-brain analysis not explicitly stated, so include for full-text review to confirm.

Abstract reports fMRI during a facial emotion recognition task (social processing) in healthy subjects and describes activity across multiple brain regions (suggesting whole-brain results). However, participant ages (18–60) are not specified and whole-brain analysis is not explicitly stated, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports results for participants with autism (a psychiatric/neurological disorder). The exclusion criteria state studies reporting results among such participants must be excluded. Although healthy controls were included, presence of a clinical group clearly meets exclusion.

fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adults; abstract describes neural activations for social vs non-social tasks and no ROI-only or clinical samples. However participant ages and whether whole-brain analyses were used are not specified. Include for full-text review to confirm age range (18–60) and whole-brain results.

Study focuses on autism spectrum disorder (ASD) participants (psychiatric/neurological disorder). Inclusion requires healthy adults 18-60; this clearly reports results among a clinical population, so it should be excluded.

Study participants are children (NVLD, ASD, and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Also includes clinical groups (NVLD, ASD), which are exclusionary. Abstract does not indicate an fMRI social task in healthy adult participants.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and appears to involve intraoperative cortical stimulation in neurosurgical patients rather than healthy adults. Thus it does not meet the task-based fMRI or healthy participant inclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review/meta-analysis of oxytocin and vasopressin neuroimaging, not an original fMRI study. The abstract indicates a review of pharmacological fMRI and imaging genetics findings rather than reporting primary fMRI data on healthy adults performing social tasks or whole-brain results; therefore it meets exclusion criteria (systematic review/meta-analysis).

This paper is a systematic review of studies on the mirror neuron system in autism, not an original fMRI study. Exclusion criteria explicitly disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses. It also focuses on autism rather than healthy adults and provides no primary whole-brain fMRI results in healthy 18–60 participants.

Includes participants with congenital insensitivity to pain (a neurological disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Although healthy controls are mentioned, presence of the patient group warrants exclusion based on abstract information.

This article is a systematic review of fMRI/DTI studies in patients with autism spectrum disorder, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a review/meta-analysis and reports data from clinical populations, so it meets exclusion criteria (systematic review and patient sample). Abstract lacks info on a single task in healthy adults or whole-brain results.

Narrative review article summarizing decades of research rather than an original fMRI study. Abstract does not report an fMRI experiment with human participants performing a social task, participant ages, or whole-brain results. Meets exclusion (not original empirical fMRI study).

Participants are infants (4–7 months), not healthy adults (18–60). The study therefore does not match the review population; additionally the task involved passive listening while asleep rather than an adult social task. Exclude based on age/population mismatch.

Healthy adult participants (15M,15F) underwent fMRI during a Body Perception task comparing own vs other bodies, which is social-related processing. Abstract describes whole-brain activation patterns (not ROI) and does not involve clinical populations. Ages not explicitly stated; include for full-text to confirm age range and full methods.

Single-case report of an 8-year-old with massive bilateral frontal damage (neurological disorder), not healthy adults (age 18-60). Also not focused on a social-task fMRI in healthy adult participants. Meets exclusion criteria for participants with neurological disorders and age ineligible.

fMRI study of social cognition (self/other reflection) in healthy Chinese adults; reports neural activity in multiple whole-brain regions (mPFC, TPJ, insula, hippocampus) rather than ROI-only results; no psychiatric/neurological populations. Age not explicitly stated beyond 'adults' but likely within 18–60; full text can confirm if needed.
Participants are adolescents (ages 12–18) and the sample includes individuals with autism spectrum disorder. Does not meet inclusion of healthy adults aged 18–60; thus excluded.

Abstract explicitly reports results from a predefined ROI (dorsomedial PFC) and frames main findings in that ROI; no whole-brain results are reported. This meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting only ROI analyses.

Abstract addresses social processing (perception and production of prosody; links with empathy) but does not explicitly state use of fMRI, participant health/ages, or whole-brain analyses. Insufficient information in abstract to confirm MRI methodology or sample; include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The article is a quantitative meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic review/meta-analysis), not an original fMRI study. This meets the explicit exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses.'

This article is explicitly a review ('In this review...') rather than a primary fMRI study. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses. Abstract also lacks clear primary whole-brain results, participant details, or task description.

The study includes participants diagnosed with schizophrenia and reports results for this clinical group. The exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so despite using fMRI on a social task with healthy controls, the presence of a patient group warrants exclusion.

fMRI study of social tasks (cooperation vs competition) in human participants; abstract reports whole-brain hemodynamic contrasts and specific activated regions (not ROI-only); sample appears to be healthy adults; not a review or clinical sample. Meets inclusion criteria.

This is a systematic review of neuroimaging in patients with major depressive and bipolar disorders (clinical population) rather than primary fMRI studies in healthy adults. It is also a review article (systematic review), matching exclusion criteria.

Abstract describes study of mothers with depression and affectively ill dyads (psychiatric disorders). Review requires healthy adults only; presence of clinical participants clearly excludes this study. Insufficient evidence of whole-brain healthy-adult fMRI results.

fMRI study investigating processing of goal-directed actions/intentions (social-related). Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not specify age range or whole-brain vs ROI analyses. No exclusion criteria are clearly met from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to confirm participant health/ages and whole-brain results.

Participants are individuals with autism spectrum disorder. The study reports fMRI results in a psychiatric/neurological disorder sample, violating the criterion requiring healthy adult participants (age 18–60). Although it uses a social task, the population excludes it.

Abstract reports activation in an 'independently localized region' of mPFC associated with self-reference, indicating an ROI-based analysis and does not mention whole-brain results. This meets the exclusion criterion for ROI analyses.

fMRI study involving a social-related task (participants judged meanings of their own/others' LEGO models) reporting whole-brain activations (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus, ACC, insula). Age range not specified; include for full-text review to confirm health status and ages 18–60.

This is a narrative review on adolescent brain maturation (not an original fMRI study). It discusses adolescent (not adult) findings and is a review article, so it does not provide whole-brain fMRI results in healthy adults performing social tasks.

Abstract mentions neural correlates of mentalizing but does not specify using task-based fMRI, participant health/ages, or whole-brain results. Insufficient information to determine inclusion based on abstract alone; include for full-text review to assess imaging modality, task, sample health/age, and analysis type.

Study includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (a neurodevelopmental/psychiatric condition); exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders.

fMRI study of social-related processing (recognition of action ‘vitality forms’) with reported whole-brain activation contrasts (how vs what). Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adults, so information is insufficient to confirm inclusion criteria fully—include for full-text review.

This is a literature review of atypical hemispheric specialization in ASD rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract presents a review/meta-analysis, with no primary fMRI task, participants, or whole-brain results reported. Meets exclusion criterion: systematic reviews/meta-analyses (and insufficient info to assess fMRI task or healthy adult sample).

Non-human primate study (monkey). The study used fMRI with electrical microstimulation in monkeys rather than functional MRI in healthy human adults performing a social-related task, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The study reports fMRI results for participants with autism spectrum disorder. Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders; presence of ASD participants excludes it.

Abstract provides insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria: it does not state that a task-based fMRI was used (could be resting-state), participant health status/ages are not specified, nor whether whole-brain results are reported. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study where participants performed an aesthetic-rating task that elicited Theory-of-Mind/social-cognition regions (PCC/PC, arMFC, TPJ). Participants are described as healthy male non-musicians (adults), whole-brain contrasts reported (not ROI-only). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and additional details.

Study includes cannabis-dependent participants (substance use disorder), i.e., a clinical population rather than exclusively healthy adults. This meets the exclusion criterion of reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders.

Resting-state fMRI study (no social task) and includes participants diagnosed with social anxiety disorder. Does not meet inclusion criteria of task-based social processing in healthy adults and includes psychiatric patients.

Abstract does not specify that an fMRI was performed during a social-related task, nor does it report participant ages/health or whole-brain results. No exclusion criteria are clearly met. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone — include for full-text review to assess imaging modality, task, sample health/age, and analysis type.

fMRI study involving recall of collective (social) memories, indicating social-cognitive processing. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analyses (mentions dorsal mPFC focus). Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult age range and whole-brain results.

Abstract reports fMRI during a social task (charades; gestural communication) and uses whole-brain directed influence mapping. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; insufficient detail to confirm age range and explicit healthy sample. Include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (18–60) and that whole-brain results are reported.

fMRI used while participants made empathy/forgiveness social judgments (social-related task). Abstract reports whole-brain activations across multiple regions (not ROI-only). Participants described as volunteers with no mention of psychiatric/neurological disorders. Age range not stated—insufficient in abstract to confirm 18–60—so include for full-text review.

Study examines cognitive deficits in schizophrenia (psychiatric population), not healthy adults. Abstract does not describe fMRI during a social-related task or reporting whole-brain results. Meets exclusion for studies with psychiatric participants; exclude.

Study uses an fMRI face-emotional processing paradigm (socially relevant task) and reports ICA-based neural modulation (suggesting whole-brain analysis). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (18–60). No exclusion criteria clearly met; include for full-text review to confirm demographics and whole-brain results.

This is a review/special-issue overview, not an original fMRI study. Abstract reports a review of mirror neuron findings and methods, with no primary data, participants, social-task fMRI, or whole-brain results—meets exclusion for systematic reviews.

Event-related fMRI in healthy adults (n=26) using a social-context/empathy-for-pain task; whole-brain activations reported (aMCC, insula, TPJ, mPFC, etc.). Not an ROI-only study, not a review, and participants appear healthy. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports voxelwise modeling confined to scene-selective regions (PPA, RSC, OPA), indicating ROI-focused analyses rather than whole-brain results. Also the task was passive viewing of movies (not a clearly defined social task), so it does not clearly meet the social-task criterion.

This is a narrative review about social cognition in bipolar disorder (psychiatric population), not an original fMRI study of healthy adults. It is a review article and involves clinical participants, so it fails inclusion criteria (healthy participants) and meets exclusion (systematic review/meta-analytic or review of patient data).

The sample comprises individuals with borderline personality disorder (clinical population). The review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so this study does not meet the healthy-participant inclusion criterion.

Functional MRI was used during facial emotion processing (a social-related task). Participants are non-clinical groups (excessive smartphone users vs normal controls) with no reported psychiatric/neurological disorders, and results report whole-brain neural activations/deactivations (no ROI-only analysis mentioned). Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm ages (18–60) and whole-brain analysis details.

Participants are adolescents including individuals with anorexia nervosa (a psychiatric disorder); review requires healthy adults aged 18–60. Therefore study does not meet participant-age or health criteria.
Participants are pediatric (youth) including patients with bipolar disorder and high-risk youth, not healthy adults aged 18–60. Thus population criterion not met; excludes study.

Includes participants with schizophrenia (clinical sample) and healthy controls; exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Abstract describes ROI-based analyses (sensorimotor ROIs) and does not report whole-brain results.

fMRI study investigating spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception—a social cognitive process. Participants were scanned during a task engaging social information (faces linked to behaviors). Abstract does not specify participant ages/health or whether analyses were whole-brain vs ROI, so include for full-text eligibility determination.

Participants are early adolescents (developmental study), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Additionally, the study used ROIs defined from ALE meta-analyses and examined activity within those regions (ROI-based approach), not whole-brain results.

Abstract reports an fMRI deception task (social processing) but does not clearly state participant health status or whether whole-brain results were reported. Mention of ‘psychopathic traits’ suggests possible clinical sample, so full-text needed to determine eligibility.

fMRI study where healthy volunteers performed a social-related self/familiar/unknown face recognition task; authors report whole-brain contrasts across frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital regions. Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm ages and whole-brain (non-ROI) methods.

Not an fMRI experiment: this is a methodological/review article about magnetoencephalography (MEG), not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Also not reporting whole-brain fMRI results or tasks.

Forty healthy volunteers underwent fMRI while viewing masked and unmasked facial emotions (a social-related task). The abstract reports activations across multiple brain regions (thalamus, temporo-parietal, cerebellum, amygdala, cortical areas), indicating whole-brain results rather than ROI-only. Participants are healthy adults and no psychiatric/neurological disorders are reported, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI social threat reactivity task in adult participants (survivors and controls) but does not specify whole-brain results or whether the breast cancer survivor group meets the review’s ‘healthy adults’ criterion. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review to confirm sample health status and that whole-brain analyses were reported.

Study includes participants with Autism Spectrum Disorder (a clinical population) and healthy controls rather than only healthy adults; it is a diagnostic/classification study using structural/functional MRI rather than a task-based fMRI study of social processing. Thus it meets exclusion criteria (clinical population and not social-task fMRI).

Includes participants diagnosed with borderline personality disorder (psychiatric sample). Exclusion criterion specifies studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although fMRI during a social task and control participants are present, the presence of a clinical group warrants exclusion based on abstract.

fMRI study examining responses to empathic social feedback during a task—addresses social processing. Healthy adult participants (20, 10 male) with no disorders reported. Abstract reports activations across multiple whole-brain regions (not ROI). Age range not specified; include for full-text to confirm ages and whole-brain analysis.

fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (witnessing an emergency). Abstract reports activation changes across multiple brain regions (pre/postcentral gyri, medial frontal gyrus, visual/attention areas), consistent with whole-brain results. No indication of clinical/psychiatric sample or ROI-only analysis. Age range not specified, but otherwise meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text verification of participant ages and whole-brain methods.

This is a case study reporting fMRI results from a patient with Capgras delusion (a neurological lesion). The abstract indicates results among a participant with a neurological disorder, which meets the exclusion criterion. Inclusion of an age-matched control group does not override exclusion for studies reporting results in disordered participants.

This is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis comparing ASD and TD groups (systematic review/meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion. It also focuses on participants with autism (clinical population) rather than only healthy adults performing social tasks.

fMRI study of social nonverbal processing (viewing/imitating/producing facial expressions and hand gestures) in humans. Abstract reports activation locations consistent with whole-brain analysis and does not indicate clinical populations. Age range not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 criterion and that whole-brain results are reported.

The study reports results for participants with traumatic brain injury (diffuse axonal injury), a neurological disorder. The review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Presence of a clinical patient group (even with healthy controls) meets exclusion criteria.

Study uses fMRI during social judgments about people, but the abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain versus ROI analyses. Key inclusion criteria (age 18–60 and whole-brain results) are unclear, so include for full-text review.

The abstract indicates the sample comprised early adolescent girls (adolescents), not healthy adults aged 18–60. This fails the age inclusion criterion, so the study should be excluded based on the abstract.

fMRI study using a social task (honesty/trust) with multivariate whole-brain results reported across multiple regions (PCC, DLPFC, IPS, VMPFC, TPJ). Not an ROI-only study or review, and no patient population indicated. Age range not specified in abstract, so full text should confirm eligibility.

Abstract describes fMRI experiments of social/mentalizing tasks in humans and reports neural representations in ToM regions. It does not indicate ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. However participant health/age and whether whole-brain results were reported are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and whole-brain analyses.

Abstract describes a case-control sample including people with severe mental illness and controls. The study reports results among psychiatric participants (not exclusively healthy adults), which meets the exclusion criterion. Insufficient evidence that results are limited to healthy 18–60 adults.

Participants are children (developmental sample), not healthy adults aged 18–60, and the study includes an autism spectrum disorder clinical group. Thus it does not meet the healthy adult participant inclusion criterion.

fMRI study investigating neural responses to own vs others' body parts (social information/self-recognition), relevant to social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status or whether results are whole-brain versus ROI-only. Insufficient detail to exclude, so include for full-text review.

Abstract reports results from participants with Autism Spectrum Disorder (a psychiatric/neurological disorder). Inclusion criteria require healthy participants only; presence of a clinical group meets an exclusion criterion, so the study should be excluded.

fMRI study of social cognition (impression formation) in human participants; reports whole-brain activation in dorsal mPFC rather than ROI-only results; no indication of clinical sample. Age range not specified but likely healthy adults; include for full-text verification of participant ages and whole-brain methods.

Abstract reports results for individuals with schizophrenia (a psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so exclude despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Abstract reports results from individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (a psychiatric/neurological disorder). The review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders, so the study should be excluded despite involving fMRI social tasks in healthy adults.

This is a narrative review of the neurobiology of social phobia, not an original fMRI study. It does not report functional MRI data in healthy adults or whole-brain results; it's a review/meta-discussion and thus not eligible for inclusion.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social cognition (movie-based MASC task) with whole-brain model-based and model-free analyses; however participant health status and ages (18–60) are not specified in the abstract. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The abstract indicates the study examines individuals with autistic-spectrum disorder (a clinical population), not healthy adults. This violates the inclusion criterion of healthy participants and meets the exclusion criterion for studies with psychiatric/neurological disorders; therefore exclude.

fMRI study with healthy ("normal volunteers") adults performing social-related tasks (emotion identification and attribution). No evidence of ROI-only analyses or clinical participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to confirm these criteria.

fMRI study of decisions to share news articles with others, addressing social-related processing (sharing, perspective-taking). Abstract reports neural activity across multiple regions (implying whole-brain) and does not mention clinical samples or ROI-only analyses. Participant age/health and explicit whole-brain claim are not stated, so include for full-text review to confirm.

fMRI study involving action observation/execution (mirror system), which is social-related processing in healthy human participants. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain versus ROI analyses. Because key inclusion details (ages 18–60, whole-brain results) are unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm these criteria.

fMRI study of social-related narrative processing in 78 healthy adult participants; abstract reports activation in posterior medial, mPFC, and temporo-parietal cortices (suggesting whole-brain results). Age range not specified and whole-brain analysis not explicitly stated, so include for full-text review to confirm ages (18–60) and full-brain analyses.

Study reports results in adults with autism (a clinical/psychiatric/neurodevelopmental disorder). Exclusion criterion 'studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders' is met; exclude regardless of task or analysis details.

Participants are adolescents (aged 11.1–15.5 years), outside the review’s required adult age range (18–60). Although the study used fMRI during a social task and reports neural activations, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study of implicit interpersonal (social) processing with reported neural effects (dorsal striatum). Double-blind placebo-controlled in (presumably) healthy adults; no mention of psychiatric/neurological sample or ROI-only analyses. Abstract does not explicitly state whole-brain results or participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analyses and age range.

This is a conceptual primer/commentary, not an empirical fMRI study. The abstract reports no functional MRI scans, no participant sample or social task, and no whole-brain results. Insufficient to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study scanning participants while viewing film clips of people in distress (social task). Participants are expert practitioners (no patient population mentioned), implying healthy adults. Abstract reports whole-brain activation patterns (ventral striatum, mOFC) rather than ROI-only results. Age range not specified but likely adult; include for full-text review to confirm ages and whole-brain reporting.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of a social task (one-shot anonymous prisoner’s dilemma) and reports activations in multiple social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus), indicating whole-brain results rather than ROI-only; no clinical population is mentioned. Age range not specified in abstract, so full text should be checked, but nothing in the abstract meets exclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

This is a review article summarizing neuroimaging findings in autism (a clinical population), not an original fMRI study of healthy adults performing social tasks. It focuses on autistic participants and is a review, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants are two young children with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults (age 18–60). Study population and clinical diagnosis clearly violate inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with a social communicative speech task in healthy adult native Japanese speakers learning L2. Abstract reports whole-brain activations (pSMG, MTG, OFC) and no psychiatric/neurological disorders. Age range not explicitly stated, but participant description and results suggest typical healthy adult sample; include for full-text review to confirm ages and analytic details.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no social-task), and includes participants with Autism Spectrum Disorder (clinical population). It therefore does not meet the review’s requirement for task-based social processing in healthy adults and includes a psychiatric group.

Task-based fMRI assessing social processing (‘feeling addressed’) in healthy adult participants (n=37); reports whole-brain activation (ACC, fusiform gyrus, SMA, IFG, insula). No indication of patient sample or ROI-only analyses. Include for full-text review.

Study includes participants with a first episode of psychosis (psychiatric patients). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although the task (facial emotion processing) is social and likely fMRI, inclusion of a clinical group warrants exclusion based on the provided criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of human participants performing perception/discrimination of affective (social) vocalisations and reports neural responses in superior temporal regions (implying whole-brain results). Participant age/health not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants are adolescents (not adults 18–60) and the clinical groups include depressed adolescents with suicidal ideation/attempts (psychiatric sample). Does not meet the healthy adult (18–60) inclusion criterion; exclusion clear from abstract.

fMRI study examining neural responses to biological vs scrambled motion (nonverbal social stimuli), which fits social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or confirm healthy status, nor explicitly state whole-brain versus ROI analyses; therefore include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (person perception and mentalising) in humans during a task linking bodies/names with trait statements. No indication of clinical participants or that results are ROI-only, but age range and whole-brain reporting are not specified in the abstract—insufficient info to exclude. Recommend full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (18–60) and whole-brain results.

The study includes and reports results from participants diagnosed with social anxiety disorder (psychiatric disorder). The review exclusion criteria exclude studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so it should be excluded despite including healthy controls and fMRI data.

fMRI study of self-referential (social) processing in 20 adult women with reported activations in medial PFC, cingulate, and temporoparietal cortex, suggesting whole-brain results. Abstract lacks explicit ages and explicit statement of healthy status; include for full-text verification.

Not an fMRI task-based study: it reports structural volumetric (manual tracing) differences in fusiform gyrus. Also includes participants with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome (clinical group), not healthy-only. Does not report task-based social fMRI whole-brain results. Therefore excluded.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social (and nonsocial) attribution tasks and identifies brain regions (DMPFC), suggesting whole-brain analyses. Participant health and ages not specified in abstract. Because some inclusion criteria (healthy adults, age range, whole-brain explicitly) are not fully confirmed, include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Article is an overview/review of social neuroscience rather than an original fMRI study. Abstract lacks primary methods, participant details, specific fMRI task data, and whole-brain results; appears to be a narrative review.

fMRI study with participants performing an emotional classification task (social processing). Abstract reports whole-brain activations across multiple regions (amygdala, vPCC, STG, thalamus, etc.), is not a review, and does not mention patient populations. Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm participant ages (18–60) and whole-brain analysis details.

fMRI study in healthy adults investigating self/other social processing during recollection; reports whole-brain activation distinctions in mPFC (not limited to ROIs). No indication of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses. Abstract provides sufficient evidence of a social-related task with fMRI, so include for full-text review.

This is an editorial/introduction to a special issue, not an original empirical fMRI study. The abstract describes reviews and theoretical articles; no task-based fMRI on healthy adult participants or whole-brain results are reported.

fMRI study of social expectancy violations (warmth/competence) during a social task; no indication of psychiatric/neurological participants or ROI-only analyses. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health/ages or confirm whole-brain reporting, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Participants are children aged 7–13 and include individuals with autism spectrum disorder; the review requires healthy adults aged 18–60. Thus population does not match inclusion criteria and meets exclusion criteria (psychiatric/neurological disorder).

Study includes adults with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Although healthy controls were included, the presence and reporting of results in an ASD clinical group warrants exclusion based on the abstract.

The article appears to be a review of neuroimaging studies (not a primary fMRI experiment). Inclusion criterion excludes systematic reviews/meta-analyses. Abstract provides no primary participant/task/whole-brain results details; therefore exclude based on study type.

fMRI study examining Theory of Mind during social exchange (Wason selection task) that reports activation of ToM-related brain areas. Not a review, no patient population mentioned, and contrasts imply whole-brain neuroimaging results rather than ROI-only analyses.

Study examines children (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 18–60, and includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/neurodevelopmental condition). Thus it does not meet the population inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI during a social task (ultimatum game) in healthy participants but does not specify participant ages or whether whole-brain results were reported. Because age range (18–60) and whole-brain analyses cannot be confirmed from the abstract, include for full-text review.

Study examines brain function in people with Asperger syndrome (a neurodevelopmental/neuropsychiatric disorder). This fails the ‘healthy participants’ inclusion criterion, so the study should be excluded.

fMRI study in healthy adults measuring neural responses during emotion regulation of idiographic negative self-beliefs. Abstract does not clearly state this is a social-related task nor explicitly report whole-brain results vs. ROI. Insufficient information to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm social relevance and whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study in healthy adults performing a social judgment task (social dominance in faces). Abstract reports whole-brain activation clusters (bilateral DLPFC, DMPFC/ACC, AI, ventral visual cortex). Participant ages not specified (18–60 criterion unconfirmed), so include for full-text review to verify age range and full methods.

Study population consists of patients with bipolar disorder (clinical sample), which violates the inclusion criterion requiring healthy participants; therefore excluded despite using fMRI on a social task.

fMRI study examining attentional orienting by social gaze cues (social-related task) reporting whole-brain neural activity (ventral frontoparietal network). No indication of psychiatric/neurological disorders. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults 18–60.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI in healthy participants engaging in third-party punishment (a social cognition task). No indication of psychiatric/neurological disorders or that it is a review. However age range (18–60) and explicit statement of whole-brain results are not provided in the abstract, so full-text is needed to confirm eligibility.

Participants are a chronic traumatic brain injury population (neurological disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders, so the study must be excluded despite using fMRI on social (face) stimuli.

Study focuses on autism spectrum disorders and mirror neuron dysfunction in ASD participants and appears to be a review of evidence (fMRI, TMS, EEG) rather than a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Does not report an fMRI task in healthy adults, whole-brain results, or primary data. Therefore excluded.

Large-sample task fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Human Connectome Project) includes a social-processing task and reports whole-brain task activations and resting-state networks. Not an ROI study, not a review, and not in clinical populations.

Abstract reports fMRI during social (altruistic) choice and dietary choice, uses multivariate decoding identifying DLPFC, precuneus, TPJ—consistent with whole-brain analyses. No indication of ROI-only analyses, clinical populations, or being a review. Participant health/ages not explicitly stated, but study design and journal imply healthy adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm demographics and whole-brain reporting.

Participants are adolescent girls (recruited based on peer victimization reports from grades 2–8), i.e., under 18. Inclusion requires healthy adults aged 18–60, so the sample falls outside the eligible age range.

Abstract reports fMRI during a social task (mental-state decoding/"Reading the Mind in the Eyes") in native Japanese and white American participants, and neural correlates (bilateral pSTS) are reported—consistent with whole-brain analysis. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract. Include for full-text to confirm ages (18–60) and whole-brain reporting.

Abstract reports fMRI of person-perception and mentalizing (social processing) using human/robot avatars and belief manipulation. Participant health/ages and explicit whole-brain versus ROI analyses are not specified; no clear exclusion criteria met. Insufficient detail to confirm whole-brain or ages, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Functional MRI study of gaze (social) processing in 30 healthy participants reporting whole-brain psychophysiological interaction connectivity results. Age range not specified (insufficient information to confirm 18–60), so include for full-text review to verify eligibility and whole-brain analyses.

fMRI study examining social auditory cues (one vs two people walking) reporting activation of social brain areas. No psychiatric/neurological disorders mentioned and whole-brain activations are described rather than ROI-only. Age range not specified—include for full-text review to confirm participant ages (18–60) and full methods/results.

fMRI study of subjects observing a human demonstrator performing toolmaking—addresses social cognition (motor resonance, mentalizing). Abstract reports whole-brain activations across multiple regions (premotor, parietal, medial PFC) rather than ROI-only results. Participants described as Naïve/Trained/Expert (presumably healthy adults); ages not specified, so full text needed to confirm 18–60 and other details. Include for full-text review to verify participant ages and whole-brain analysis methods.

This is an overview/review of molecular neuroimaging (neuroeconomics) rather than an original fMRI study reporting whole-brain results in healthy adults. It is a review article, matching the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses (non-original research).

Abstract reports results from patients with borderline personality disorder in addition to healthy controls. Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although a social fMRI task and healthy adults are included, the presence of patient-group results warrants exclusion.

Abstract reports fMRI hemodynamic responses to child stimuli (a social-related task), which fits the review objective. However the abstract does not specify participant ages/health status or whether whole-brain (vs ROI) analyses were used. Insufficient detail—include for full-text review.

Participants are patients with mild traumatic brain injury (neurological disorder), not healthy adults; the intervention is a rehabilitation music task, not a social-related fMRI task. Thus it fails inclusion criteria (healthy participants and social-task relevance).

The task involved repeating real words and pseudowords (speech production/aging), not a social-related task. Abstract does not indicate social interaction paradigms. Participants’ ages unspecified but main exclusion is lack of social processing task.

Abstract reports results from a mixed sample including patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls. Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders; therefore the study is excluded.

This is a review article discussing infant and macaque fMRI data and theoretical mechanisms, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults performing social tasks. It is a review (excluded) and focuses on infants, so does not meet the adult healthy participant or original whole-brain fMRI study criteria.

fMRI investigation of gaze-direction (a social cue) during face processing, reporting activations in fusiform, amygdala and intraparietal sulcus. No indication participants had psychiatric/neurological disorders or that analyses were ROI-only. Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain analysis details.

Abstract reports neural responses in human pSTS to stimuli depicting social interactions, indicating an fMRI univariate contrast of social processing in healthy adults and not an ROI or clinical sample. Although the abstract is brief and does not explicitly state participant ages or full-brain coverage, it addresses social processing in humans and warrants full-text review to confirm methods and whole-brain results.

This is a theoretical/explanatory paper (review-style) discussing accounts of mirror-touch synesthesia; the abstract does not report any original fMRI experiment, participant details, a social task, or whole-brain results. It appears to be a review/theory article rather than an fMRI study of healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are individuals with autism (a clinical/psychiatric population), not healthy adults aged 18–60. The review seeks fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults, so this study is not eligible based on participant diagnosis.

Study reports results from patients with paranoid schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Presence of a clinical participant group meets exclusion criterion 'participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders'. Although fMRI ToM task and healthy controls are included, the study is ineligible for a review limited to healthy adults.

Participants are children (high-functioning autistic child, Asperger’s child, and normal children) and include clinical diagnoses. Inclusion requires healthy adults aged 18–60; both age and participant health criteria are not met. Exclude based on these clear criteria.

fMRI study of communicative (social) speech tasks in healthy adult native Japanese speakers learning English as L2; abstract reports whole-brain activation (pSMG, MTG, OFC) and does not indicate ROI-only analyses or clinical samples. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain reporting.

Study includes participants with autism spectrum conditions (clinical population). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders; therefore the study does not meet the healthy-only participant criterion.

The article is a summary/review of psychopharmacological and fMRI research rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract indicates it is a review (not primary data), provides no participant, task, or whole-brain results—meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and not reporting original fMRI results.

Study reports data from individuals with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population) alongside neurotypical controls. Review requires healthy adult participants only and excludes studies with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Abstract clearly indicates ASD participants; therefore exclude.

Abstract reports fMRI experiments examining emotional empathy/egocentricity bias (a social-related task) with reported brain activations (rSMG), suggesting whole-brain analyses; no evidence of patient samples or ROI-only analyses. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 18–60 criterion and whole-brain reporting.

fMRI study examining social perception (spatial relations between two bodies) in healthy adult participants; reports neural responses in visual/body-selective cortical regions (inferior lateral occipital cortex, body-selective cortex), implying whole-brain mapping rather than ROI-only analyses. No clinical populations. Meets social-task and healthy adult criteria; include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain reporting details.

Abstract reports results from schizophrenia patients (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders is met, so the study must be excluded despite using fMRI and whole-brain analyses.

Study focuses on patients with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Abstract indicates investigation of deficits in schizophrenia rather than fMRI in healthy adults; thus does not meet inclusion criterion of healthy participants.

This study used structural MRI covariance analysis, not functional MRI during a social task, and included participants with autism spectrum conditions (clinical population). It therefore does not meet the fMRI and healthy-participant inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using neutral faces in goal-relevant vs. goal-irrelevant situations (social processing). Abstract reports whole-brain activations (ACC, ventral striatum, VTA, SN, STS) and no indication of clinical samples; likely healthy adults. Meets fMRI social-task and whole-brain criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study of action recognition/social cognition in healthy adults; abstract describes neural responses to observed human actions. However, abstract does not specify participant ages or whether results are whole-brain vs ROI, so insufficient info to confirm all inclusion criteria — include for full-text review.

Abstract reports results from participants with schizophrenia (nonparanoid and paranoid groups) in addition to controls, and uses analyses of mean percent signal change extracted from a priori regions of interest (ROI). This violates inclusion criteria for healthy-only samples and excludes ROI-only results.

Study reports fMRI results from patients with a neurological disorder (ALS) rather than exclusively healthy adults; inclusion criteria require healthy participants and exclusion disallows studies reporting results among neurological disorders. Therefore excluded based on participant population.

Participants are described as 'male adolescents' (likely under 18), which does not meet the inclusion age range of 18–60. Other criteria (task, whole-brain analysis) are met, but the age exclusion is clear from the abstract.

Abstract describes dfMRI of face-to-face social interaction relevant to social processing in humans but lacks details on participant health/ages and whether whole-brain analyses were reported. Insufficient information to confirm all inclusion criteria from abstract alone, so include for full-text review.

Event-related fMRI study of mirror-system responses to heard/observed actions (social cognition: understanding others’ actions). Abstract reports whole-brain activations (left inferior frontal and posterior temporal regions) and no clinical population or ROI-only analysis. Participant age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Study uses resting-state fMRI (no social task) and reports results from DM1 patients (neurological disorder). Does not meet task-based fMRI or healthy-participant inclusion criteria.

The study examines self/other-processing in individuals with schizophrenia (a psychiatric disorder). This does not meet the inclusion criterion of healthy adult participants; thus it should be excluded.

This is a review/perspective on the field of social neuroscience rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract describes field overview and future directions, provides no participant, task, or whole-brain fMRI results, and meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study of social processing (allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgements) in 22 healthy adult male participants; reports whole-brain activations (multiple cortical regions). Not ROI-only or clinical sample.

Abstract does not report use of functional MRI; it describes coherence spectral-density analysis of simultaneously measured cerebral activity (likely EEG/MEG hyperscanning). Thus it fails the required 'functional MRI' modality. Whole-brain results are not specified.

Study examines individuals with autism spectrum disorder (a neurodevelopmental/psychiatric disorder), not healthy adults. It focuses on executive dysfunction and network hub architecture rather than an fMRI social-related task in healthy participants. Therefore it fails inclusion criteria (wrong population and not a social task).

Abstract reports an fMRI task involving social interaction (reaction-time competition vs opponents) probing neural correlates of reactive aggression. However, it does not explicitly state participant health status, ages, or confirm whole-brain (versus ROI) analyses. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria from abstract alone, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adults (18–60) and whole-brain results.

Participants are youth (not adults) and include a clinical group with Disruptive Behavior Disorders; the review requires healthy adult participants aged 18–60. This clearly meets exclusion criteria (psychiatric/younger sample).

fMRI study of social-emotional perception (dynamic crowd interactions), fitting the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain results, nor does it indicate clinical samples or ROI-only analyses. Insufficient detail to confirm all inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and whole-brain reporting.

fMRI study reporting whole-brain activation during tasks involving affective creativity (generating reappraisals for anger-evoking events) and classic divergent thinking; authors note recruitment of regions implicated in social cognition. No indication of clinical populations or ROI-only analyses in the abstract. Participant health status and ages not explicitly reported, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and included participants with psychotic disorder (not healthy-only). Thus it does not meet the task-based social processing and healthy adult criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI activation during a social/olfactory evaluation task (detection/preference for self vs non-self MHC peptides) in volunteers. However, ages (18–60) and whether analyses were whole-brain vs ROI are not specified; include for full-text review.

Study uses simultaneous fMRI during a social (mother–infant bonding) task in healthy adult mothers, but the abstract does not specify participant ages or whether whole-brain results (vs. ROI/network-only analyses) were reported. Include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain reporting and eligibility.

fMRI study of social cognition (predicting others' mental states) in male and female human participants with no mention of psychiatric/neurological disorders. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60) or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI-only analyses. Insufficient info to confirm age range and whole-brain results, so include for full-text review.

The study investigates memory control and recognition processes (fcMRI, cueing recognition task) rather than social-related processing. It does not involve a social task, so it fails the review’s primary inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports fMRI during a social decision-making task (charitable giving) and an EmpaToM fMRI task, identifying neural loci (AI, TPJ, pSTS) consistent with whole-brain analyses. Participants appear to be healthy adults; however age range (18–60) is not specified. No ROI-only, patient, or review study exclusion is evident. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain reporting.

fMRI study where participants made social judgments (faces after cooperative/defector interactions) — clearly a social task. Abstract reports distributed whole-brain activations (amygdala, insula, fusiform, STS, reward areas), not ROI-only. No indication of psychiatric/neurological sample. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages (18–60) and whole-brain analysis details.

Abstract describes a review/case study series of ecstatic epilepsy and related phenomena using multiple imaging modalities and includes patients with neurological disorders. It is not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults and appears to be a review, so it fails inclusion criteria.

Article is a narrative review summarizing research programs including participants with autism and children; not an original fMRI study of healthy adults (18–60) performing social tasks. Abstract does not report whole-brain results for healthy adult participants and includes clinical populations, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring empathy (social processing) while participants viewed human and robot experiencing pain/pleasure. Healthy adult participants implied; no psychiatric/neurological disorders reported. Whole-brain analyses are reported (and ROI analyses are not sole results). Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI studies where participants considered others' mental states (social task), is not a review, and reports neural (likely whole-brain) analyses across four studies. No indication of patient populations or ROI-only analyses. Although age range (18–60) is not specified, no exclusion criteria are clearly met, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain results.
Participants are children (mean age ~10 years), not healthy adults aged 18–60 required by the review. Abstract clearly states pediatric sample, so it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study of social face processing in human participants performing attention tasks; abstract implies whole-brain multivariate patterns but lacks explicit participant health/age and whole-brain vs ROI detail. Insufficient info to exclude, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study presenting social interaction video stimuli to a non-clinical sample of young adult males; tasks are social-related (positive and reactive-aggressive scenarios); abstract reports whole-brain activation patterns rather than ROI-only results. fMRI study in congenitally blind and sighted adults performing voice-based identity and emotion recognition—a social-related task. Participants appear healthy but ages (18–60) are not reported, and the abstract does not specify whether results are whole-brain or ROI-based. Key inclusion items are therefore unclear, so include for full-text review.

Participants performed an event-related fMRI mind-perception task (social-cognitive) with subsequent behavioral social attention; analyses report whole-brain parametric results implicating vmPFC and other social regions (not ROI-only). No indication of clinical sample. Age range not specified but appears to be healthy adults. Include for full-text review.

Participants are children/adolescents (mean ages ~11–12, range 5.5–19.7) and include a clinical ASD group (not healthy adults). Study used resting-state fMRI, not a social-task fMRI in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports results from participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder) and compares patients to controls. Exclusion criterion disallows studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Although an emotional task was used, the presence of a clinical sample makes this study ineligible based on the abstract.

Participants are patients with Major Depressive Disorder (psychiatric disorder), which meets an exclusion criterion. Additionally, the study used resting-state fMRI rather than a social-related task, so it does not meet the task-based fMRI inclusion criterion.

Study used resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social processing paradigm) and includes participants with depression (psychiatric disorder). Thus it fails the inclusion criteria (task-based, healthy-only sample) and meets exclusion criteria.

This is a narrative review of adolescent neurobiology, not an original fMRI study. It focuses on adolescents (not healthy adults 18–60) and is a review article, thus clearly failing inclusion criteria.

fMRI-pupillometry study investigating pupil mimicry’s effect on trust—a social processing task—and reports recruitment of theory-of-mind regions (precuneus, TPJ, STS, mPFC), implying whole-brain results in healthy adults. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages and explicit statement of whole-brain analysis, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI experiment (N=31) examined neural responses to disfigured faces, a social-processing task; results report activations in ventral occipito-temporal cortex and anterior cingulate, consistent with whole-brain findings. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly declare whole-brain analysis or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Participants were entering psychotherapy for depression and/or anxiety (psychiatric disorders). Inclusion requires healthy participants; exclusion criteria disallow studies with psychiatric participants.

The abstract reports analyses focused on face-selective regions (posterior STS and FFA), indicating ROI-based analyses and does not mention whole-brain results. Participant health/ages are not specified, but ROI focus alone meets an exclusion criterion.

Resting-state fMRI study in young children (age 3–7) including participants with autism spectrum disorder; not a task-based social processing fMRI in healthy adults (18–60). Meets exclusion criteria (clinical population, wrong age range, not task-based).

fMRI study using a social interaction task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult men and women, reporting neural responses (VTA, amygdala). Not a review, not conducted in a clinical population, and abstract does not indicate ROI-only analyses. Include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain results and explicit age range.

fMRI study where participants made risky decisions in social scenarios (meets social-task criterion) and participants appear healthy (late adolescents and young adults). Abstract lacks exact ages and does not explicitly state whole-brain analysis, so include for full-text review to confirm age range (18+) and whole-brain results.

fMRI BOLD study of humor processing (a social-cognitive task) in 29 healthy adults with reported whole-brain activations; no psychiatric/neurological participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60 criterion) or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI analysis. Insufficient methodological detail—include for full-text review.

Participants are individuals with a psychotic disorder (psychiatric population), and the abstract describes a behavioral RCT protocol with no mention of fMRI or social-processing tasks. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of communicative intentions (social cognition) with categorical and functional connectivity analyses implying whole-brain reporting. Participants described as human subjects with no indication of psychiatric/neurological disorders. Age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and whole-brain results.

fMRI study where participants retrieved biographical (social) information during scanning, involving healthy adult participants. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI-only results, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study of social cognition (learning others' values/decisions) in humans; no indication of clinical populations. Abstract does not specify ages or whether results are whole-brain versus ROI, so include for full-text review to confirm whole-brain analysis and participant ages.

fMRI study of social processing (control of interpersonal trust/distrust) with healthy participants (n=60) and reports whole-brain activations (TPJ, precuneus, IFG, mPFC). Abstract does not indicate clinical sample or ROI-only analyses.

The study includes participants with high-functioning autism (a neurodevelopmental/psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders. Although fMRI social-task data and healthy controls are present, the inclusion of a clinical group warrants exclusion based on criteria.

Event-related fMRI study manipulating attention to angry voice prosody—clearly a social-cognition task during scanning. Abstract reports whole-brain activations (amygdala, STS, orbitofrontal cortex, cuneus) rather than ROI-only results. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults 18–60.

Abstract reports fMRI results among adults with Tourette syndrome (a neurodevelopmental/psychiatric disorder). The exclusion criteria state studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric and/or neurological disorders should be excluded, despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Abstract reports results for patients with schizophrenia spectrum disorders alongside healthy controls. The review excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders; therefore the study should be excluded.

Abstract reports fMRI during social-distance tasks (photos of friends/acquaintances) using cross-domain decoding and identifies right IPL. Likely healthy adult sample and not described as ROI-only, but ages and explicit whole-brain reporting are not stated. Key inclusion details are insufficient in abstract, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using the Trust Game (a social task) reporting activations in multiple brain regions (thalamus, ACC, dorsal anterior insula/IFG), implying whole-brain results. Participants described as Machiavellian individuals with no mention of psychiatric/neurological disorders or ROI-only analyses. Fits inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social processing (emotional facial expressions) in healthy subjects, reporting widespread activations across multiple brain regions consistent with whole-brain results. Abstract does not specify participant ages (18–60 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and analysis details.

fMRI was used while participants viewed/listened to dynamic nonverbal facial/vocal stimuli (social processing). Abstract reports activation across multiple cortical regions rather than ROI-only analyses and no clinical population is mentioned. Participant ages are not specified; include for full-text to confirm age range and whole-brain analysis.

Participants include high-risk relatives of people with schizophrenia, with a subgroup (HR+) defined by presence of positive psychiatric symptoms. Inclusion requires healthy adults only. Although task is social ToM fMRI, the sample clearly includes participants with psychiatric symptoms, meeting an exclusion criterion.

Human fMRI study examining social influence on value representations (learning about another's values). Likely healthy adult participants and a social task, but abstract does not specify participant ages or whether analyses are whole-brain vs ROI. Insufficient detail to confirm those criteria — include for full-text review.

fMRI study using event-related fMRI (with EEG) during perception of others’ emotional facial expressions—a social-related task. Participants are healthy adults (mean 29±6, within 18–60). Analysis reports whole-brain SPM results (not limited to ROI). Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion.
