Thus it fails the inclusion criterion requiring a functional MRI scan while participants completed a social-related task.

Study participants have autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric clinical population), not healthy adults; the study focuses on clinical severity and sensory-cognitive network integration rather than fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults. Therefore it meets exclusion criteria.

Study includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/neurological disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among such participants; presence of an ASD group renders the study ineligible despite inclusion of healthy controls.

Abstract reports fMRI hyperscanning during a social joint-attention task, meeting the review objective. However, it does not specify participant health status/ages or whether results are whole-brain versus ROI-only. Insufficient detail to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study includes participants with schizophrenia (psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criteria disallow studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders, so exclude despite inclusion of healthy controls and relevant fMRI social task.

Participants are individuals at ultra-high risk for psychosis (a clinical population), not healthy adults aged 18–60. This violates the inclusion criterion of healthy participants; exclusion is clear despite the task being social-related.
Participants are Tourette's syndrome patients (a psychiatric/neurological disorder), not healthy adults; therefore study does not meet the criterion of healthy participants and should be excluded.

Participants fall outside the required age range: the study includes older adults aged 65–75 and younger participants including age 17, whereas the inclusion criterion requires healthy participants aged 18–60. Thus the study does not meet the age eligibility.

Study includes participants with schizophrenia (clinical population) rather than only healthy adults, and the fMRI was resting-state (no social-related task). Focus is on patient vs control differences in reading/auditory processing, so it does not meet the requirement for task-based social processing in healthy adults.

Participants are children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Study therefore does not meet population criteria; also focuses on connectivity rather than task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports relating SRS-A scores to functional connectivity of the pregenual anterior cingulate cortex in neurotypical adults, with no mention of an fMRI social task. This appears to be a seed-based (ROI) connectivity analysis, which meets the exclusion criterion for ROI analyses and does not satisfy the task-based inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports participants with high-functioning autism/Asperger Syndrome (clinical population) and states they used ROI analyses. These violate inclusion criteria (healthy adults only and whole-brain results required).

Study addresses oxytocin effects on processing of socially relevant cues (matches review topic), but the abstract does not specify fMRI methods, participant health status (healthy adults), or whether whole-brain results vs ROI were reported. Insufficient information to rule out exclusion—include for full-text review.

Participants are individuals clinically at risk for psychosis (not healthy adults). This violates the inclusion criterion of healthy participants; exclusion criterion for studies with psychiatric/neurological participants is met.

This study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) and reports results from patients with schizophrenia and major depression (with controls). It therefore does not meet the inclusion criterion of task-based social processing in healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion of reporting patient groups.

Not a task-based social fMRI study: uses resting-state fMRI. Sample includes antipsychotic-naive adolescents with early-onset schizophrenia (clinical population) and healthy adolescents—does not study healthy adults performing a social task.

Includes participants diagnosed with major depressive disorder (psychiatric patients). Presence of a clinical group meets exclusion criterion 'participants with psychiatric disorders', so exclude despite social fMRI task.

Study examines pediatric (adolescent) participants with social anxiety disorder rather than healthy adults 18–60. This is a clinical, pediatric sample, which violates inclusion criteria (healthy adults age 18–60; excludes psychiatric populations).

Abstract implies neural mechanisms of oxytocin but does not specify use of fMRI, participant ages/health, or whole-brain analyses. Insufficient information in abstract to determine inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI task, healthy adult sample (18–60), and whole-brain results.

Task is a verbal short-term memory (phonological) span task using letters and fingerspelling, not a social-related task. Although fMRI in healthy bilingual adults likely, the study does not investigate social processing, so it does not meet the review objective.

Abstract reports fMRI in a non-clinical (healthy) cohort performing the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (a social/ToM task) and describes widespread activity versus a control task, implying whole-brain analysis. However, participant ages are not reported and whole-brain analysis is not explicitly stated. Insufficient detail to confirm age range and analytic scope—include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Study uses resting-state fMRI (fALFF), not a task-based social processing paradigm, and includes schizophrenia patients. Therefore it does not meet inclusion (task-based social fMRI in healthy adults) and meets exclusion (psychiatric participants) criteria.

Participants are adolescents with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults aged 18–60. Study used resting-state fMRI and diffusion imaging rather than a task-based social-processing fMRI. Does not meet healthy adult or task-based inclusion criteria.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in adolescents with autism (clinical population), not task-based social processing in healthy adults aged 18–60. Meets exclusion criteria for psychiatric/neurological disorder sample and not a social-task fMRI study.

Abstract reports fMRI studies comparing responses to famous people and social/conceptual words (social concept processing) in presumably healthy adults. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state whole-brain vs ROI-only analyses. Insufficient detail to confirm age range and whole-brain results, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Participants are individuals with autism spectrum disorder (clinical population), not healthy adults; task is a precision visuomotor sensorimotor task, not social-related processing. Fails inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a theory-of-mind (social) task in 109 healthy volunteers and reports whole-brain corrected activation results. Age range of participants (18–60) is not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm the age criterion.

fMRI study of perspective-taking (social cognition) in what appears to be healthy adults; reports engagement of frontoparietal brain regions (whole-brain findings suggested). No ROI-only analysis or clinical population noted. Full text needed to confirm participant ages and whole-brain methods.

The study investigates emotional processing in individuals with Huntington’s disease (a neurological disorder), not healthy adults. Inclusion requires healthy participants aged 18–60; this population violates the exclusion criterion for neurological disorders, so exclude.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and employed a targeted region-to-region (amygdala–mPFC) analysis — conflicts with inclusion criteria requiring task-based social processing and excluding ROI analyses.

Healthy adult samples (mean ages 22 and 26) with BOLD and structural data related to face-processing reported. The abstract does not state fMRI was acquired during a social-related task nor whether analyses were whole-brain versus ROI. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (n=20) performed social-related tasks (observation and imitation of communicative gestures). Abstract reports whole-brain activations (MNS and MS regions) rather than ROI-only analyses and does not indicate clinical populations. Meets inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in children/adolescents (ages 8–15), not a task-based social processing study; includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (clinical group); participants are not healthy adults aged 18–60. These clearly meet exclusion criteria.

Study includes participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric/clinical group) and compares them to typically developing boys (minors), so participants are not healthy adults aged 18–60. Therefore it fails the inclusion criteria (healthy adults) and meets the exclusion criterion of reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders.
Study used resting-state fMRI (not a task-based social processing task) and included youth with autism (clinical population), not healthy adults 18-60; therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a review summarizing brain-imaging studies (systematic/narrative review), not an original fMRI experiment. It does not report primary fMRI results of social tasks in healthy adults or whole-brain data; therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Abstract does not state whether an fMRI was used or whether whole-brain results are reported. Participants appear to be a general sample (likely healthy) but ages not specified. Insufficient information to confirm fMRI and whole-brain analyses — include for full-text review.

Study investigates borderline personality disorder participants (a psychiatric disorder). Exclusion criterion: studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders — thus excluded despite likely fMRI social task.

The study includes and reports results from participants with autism spectrum disorder (a psychiatric condition). The exclusion criteria state studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders should be excluded. Although it includes typically developing controls and whole-brain fMRI, the presence of ASD clinical participants warrants exclusion.

Study involves participants with autism spectrum disorder and uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm; participants are not healthy adults performing a social task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: This is an original fMRI study scanning healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 19–31) performing multiple social-cognitive tasks (theory of mind, face perception, biological motion, voice perception, auditory stories). Tasks are social-related and imaging was whole-brain (GLM performed across the brain; analyses focused on STS using an anatomically defined mask but are not limited to ROI-only approaches). Participants are healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The paper is not a review or meta-analysis and does not report patient samples. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria (social fMRI in healthy adults, appropriate age range, whole-brain analyses) and none of the exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not a review, not clinical).

Although this is an fMRI whole-brain study using a social task (Cyberball) with adult participants (mean age 19.85) and reports whole-brain results, the sample includes 9 participants who met criteria for social anxiety disorder (SCID). Analyses and reported results are based on the full sample (including those with SAD) rather than a healthy-only subsample. The review’s inclusion requires healthy participants (age 18–60) and excludes studies reporting results among participants with psychiatric disorders. Because the study’s sample and analyses include clinical participants, it does not meet the “healthy participants” criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study (3T, whole-brain EPI, SPM8) examining neural responses during a social task (Cyberball ball-toss) compared with a control button-press task. Participants were healthy adults (final N=31; mean age ~21, range within 18–60) with no neurological or psychiatric disorders. Analysis used whole-brain random-effects contrasts with cluster-level FWE correction; although follow-up sphere-based beta extraction/regression was performed, primary results are whole-brain (not ROI-only). The task is explicitly social (manipulation of social inclusion/interactions) and addresses social processing. No exclusion criteria (patient sample, ROI-only, review/meta-analysis) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study investigating understanding others' regret (social cognition/empathy). Healthy adult participants (Study 1: 24 adults, ages ~22–31; Study 2: 24 adults, ages 19–30) are within the 18–60 range. The task involves social-related processing (observing another player’s gambles and judging their emotional state), and data were acquired with whole-brain EPI sequences and analyzed using SPM5 with whole-brain parametric and conjunction analyses (thresholded p<0.001 uncorrected; cluster reports). No ROI-only results, no patient or disordered samples, and this is not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study employing the Taylor Aggression Paradigm, a social interaction task measuring retaliatory behavior — therefore a social-related task. Participants were healthy adults (15 male university students; mean age 22.33, within 18–60). The authors performed whole-brain, random-effects analyses and report Talairach coordinates and whole-brain statistical maps (cluster-corrected thresholds), not ROI-only results. The sample contains no psychiatric/neurological disorders and the paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Although sample size is small (N=15) and limited to young males, these are limitations rather than exclusionary criteria. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study (dual‑fMRI) in healthy adults (N=44; mean age 22.4) who performed an interactive, social Pattern Game (cooperative/competitive conditions). The protocol used whole‑brain preprocessing and GLM analyses with group-level whole‑brain random-effects inference and non‑parametric permutation correction (FSL ‘randomize’), reporting whole‑brain cluster results. Participants were healthy, within the 18–60 age range, and the paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) without ROI‑only analyses or clinical populations. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-communicative processing (comprehension of speech acts—Naming vs. Requesting) in healthy adult participants (n=18 analyzed; ages 18–41). The task is explicitly social/communicative, satisfying the review objective. Whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (group-level whole-brain contrasts with FDR correction at p<0.05), alongside ROI/SVC analyses; the presence of whole-brain results meets the inclusion requirement (not ROI-only). Participants are healthy, not clinical, and the paper is an original empirical report (not a review/meta-analysis). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=16–17 for analyses; age range 21–46) that experimentally manipulated social cognition (explicit mental-state/emotion attribution to human and non-human faces and implicit viewing of faces). The study reports whole-brain group-level analyses (cluster-forming voxel threshold p<0.001 with cluster-level FWE correction), alongside ROI analyses. Participants were screened to be neurologically and psychiatrically healthy. The task is clearly social-related (theory-of-mind/emotion attribution). It is not a review/meta-analysis and does not report results from a clinical sample or ROI-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (final N=18, mean age 21) using a one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma — a social task probing cooperation. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (contrasts for CC vs. other outcomes, context effects) with cluster-level FWE correction and lists activated regions, satisfying the ‘whole-brain results’ inclusion criterion. Although ROI analyses are also performed, they are supplemental and not the sole basis of results, so the ‘results of ROI analyses’ exclusion does not apply. Participants are healthy (no psychiatric/neurological disorders) and ages fall within 18–60. The study is primary empirical fMRI research (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This fMRI study tested vocal emotional (prosody) processing — a form of social/emotion-related processing — in healthy adults (N=36; ages 20–35). Data were acquired with whole-brain BOLD fMRI and analyzed at the whole-brain level (Power-264 parcellation, whole-brain functional connectivity and graph-theoretical measures); results reported global, nodal, and interregional whole-brain findings. No clinical or neurological populations were included and this is not a review/meta-analysis. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only results. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (social-related fMRI task, healthy participants age 18–60, whole-brain results) and no exclusion criteria are violated. Minor caveat: “social-related” is interpreted to include vocal emotional perception; confidence remains high.

This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=12; ages 20–32). The task includes social-related processing: learning and encoding facts about people (person-fact encoding) contrasted with buildings and hammers. Whole-brain analyses were performed (random-effects ANOVA, conjunction analyses, cluster-size correction across the brain) and whole-brain domain-specific and domain-general activations and functional connectivity maps are reported. The paper is not an ROI-only report, not a review/meta-analysis, and does not involve clinical/neurologic or psychiatric populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=37, ages 18–25) who performed a social-related task (observation and imitation of others’ hand actions). The design includes whole-brain analyses (random-effects SPM8, cluster-level correction) and psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity—no exclusive ROI-only results reported. Participants are healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The paper is an original empirical study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not report clinical populations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=25, mean age 25.1) where participants performed a social task in the scanner (learning others’ preference similarity). Analyses report whole-brain, cluster-corrected results (conjunctions and contrasts across the brain) rather than ROI-only findings. Participants were screened for neurological disorders and no clinical population was studied. The study is empirical (not a review/meta-analysis) and presents task-based functional MRI results relevant to social processing, meeting all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusions.

The study reports an fMRI task that explicitly probes social processing (social interaction recognition from point-light/stick-light displays). It includes a healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8, age range within reported 8–41, adults therefore within 18–60) and provides whole-brain analyses for the adult group (SI > NM contrasts, group-specific and between-group comparisons) rather than ROI-only results. Participants were healthy with no psychiatric/neurological disorders, and the paper is an original fMRI study (not a review). Although the sample is developmental (includes children/adolescents), adult-only whole-brain results are reported, so the study meets the review objective of healthy adult fMRI studies of social processing.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 18–34 across experiments) who viewed social interaction stimuli (observed dyadic interactions and interactive vs. non-interactive moving-shape displays), meeting the review’s focus on social-related processing. Whole-brain group analyses are reported (Experiment 1 shows whole-brain surface-based random-effects results with FDR-corrected clusters in right STS; Experiment 2 includes whole-brain contrasts and localization procedures), so whole-brain results are available. Although ROI/multivariate analyses are also used, the paper does not rely solely on ROI results. Participants were healthy and no clinical populations were included. The article is an original fMRI empirical study (not a review). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult humans performing a social cognition (mentalising/intentionality) task. Participants were healthy, right-handed adults (Experiment 2: N=17, mean age 22±2.9 years, within the 18–60 range). Functional MRI data were acquired during task performance and analyzed with whole-brain voxelwise analyses in SPM2; results are reported with whole-brain correction (thresholding and cluster extent determined by Monte-Carlo simulation) rather than ROI-only analyses. The design involves on-task fMRI (true/false mentalising vs factual questions), not a review/meta-analysis, and excludes clinical populations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult volunteers (final sample ages 22–38) using dynamic head-turn stimuli that are explicitly social cues (perceived gaze/attention). Participants completed a task during functional MRI acquisition. The paper reports both ROI-based analyses and whole-brain exploratory analyses (full gray-matter–masked volume) with familywise error correction, so results are not limited to ROI-only reporting. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and does not involve clinical or disordered participants. All inclusion criteria (fMRI during social-related task; healthy adults 18–60; whole-brain results) are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (female, age 20–33) that implemented a social-related task (viewing emotional pictures ‘together’ vs ‘alone’ with a friend). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (whole-brain cluster-level correction and whole-brain suprathreshold activations such as DLPFC and precuneus) in addition to ROI analyses (VS, OFC). Participants are healthy (no psychiatric/neurological disorders reported) and within the 18–60 age range. The study is not a review/meta-analysis and does not report patient samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria (fMRI during a social-related task; healthy adults 18–60; whole-brain results) are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=25; mean age 25.7) that used social-emotion tasks (recalling personal guilt memories and imagining hypothetical social/moral scenarios) during scanning. The task clearly involves social-related processing. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (thresholded p<0.001 with cluster extent) and reports whole-brain activations (e.g., posterior cingulate, inferior frontal cortices) in addition to small-volume corrections; it is not an ROI-only report. Participants were healthy with no neurological or psychiatric disorders. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This study used task-based whole-brain fMRI in healthy adults (final N=12, mean age 26 years) during action observation of another person (AO) and action execution (AE). Observing another’s effort/force to infer intention qualifies as social-related processing (action observation/imitation/mentalizing). The paper reports whole-brain GLM analyses (SPM12) with voxel-wise results and conjunctions, and also cerebellar SUIT analyses; results are not limited to ROIs. Participants were healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The study is empirical (not a review) and does not involve clinical/psychiatric populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=18; ages 18–27) while they listened to literary excerpts that were annotated for mentalizing (social cognition) and action content. The main contrasts include mentalizing-related processing and the authors report whole-brain group results (e.g., aMPFC cluster for Mentalizing > Action and Action > Mentalizing clusters), meeting the requirement for whole-brain results. Although ROI analyses and localizers were used, whole-brain analyses are reported and interpreted. Participants were healthy, within the 18–60 age range, and the task probes social-related (theory-of-mind/mentalizing) processing. No exclusion criteria (clinical samples, review-only, ROI-only reporting) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

Study used fMRI while healthy adult humans (male, 23–28 years) completed a social task (ultimatum game). Imaging included whole-brain acquisition and analyses: the paper reports offline whole-brain classification, leave-one-subject-out cross-subject models, and lists discriminating volumes (voxelwise weight maps) from SVM analyses. Participants were healthy (no psychiatric/neurological disorders) and within the 18–60 age range. Although the online analysis used predefined ROIs, the presence of whole-brain results and reported discriminating brain volumes meets the whole-brain criterion. This is an empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports whole-brain fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=60, ages 18–60) performing a social-related task (viewing human and animal suffering; empathy/social cognition). Analyses used SPM2 whole-brain random-effects models with results reported at whole-brain FWE-corrected thresholds and MNI coordinates. Participants were healthy with no neurological/psychiatric disorders, and the paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) reporting whole-brain results rather than ROI-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=21, ages 18–35) that used dynamic social interaction stimuli (videos of two actors engaging in arguing/celebrating/laughing). Participants completed an in-scanner task (passive viewing with a frame-freeze detection) while BOLD data were acquired. The paper reports whole-brain preprocessing and GLM estimation and describes whole-brain searchlight analyses (in addition to ROI analyses), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain results. The sample is healthy and within the 18–60 age range, it is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis), and it does not report clinical/psychiatric populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It used functional MRI during a social-related task — participants observed others’ hand actions (risk-taking vs. safe), an established social/action-observation paradigm probing social cognition/emotional processing. (2) Participants were healthy late-adult adolescents (18.1–22.8 years), within the 18–60 age range. They were screened for neurological/psychiatric disorders. (3) Results are reported as whole-brain analyses using SPM (whole-brain contrasts, conjunctions, and cluster-based inference), not ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated (not a review/meta-analysis, no clinical sample, no ROI-only reporting). Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies on social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction (two-person joint action with direct haptic contact—leading, following, mutual), i.e., social-related processing. Participants were healthy adult dancers (N=18 used in analyses, mean age 40.4, range within 18–60) with no history of neurological/psychiatric disease. The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects analyses (BrainVoyager), with whole-brain contrasts, FDR correction, cluster thresholds and Talairach coordinates; results are not ROI-only. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, mean age 26, right-handed, no neurological/psychiatric history) that employed social-related tasks (explicit laughter-type categorization and implicit bout-counting) during whole-brain fMRI acquisition. The paper reports whole-brain categorical and PPI connectivity analyses with cluster-level FWE correction and presents whole-brain results (in addition to ROI checks), not solely ROI-based findings. It is an original empirical study (not a review) and participants are within the 18–60 age range. No psychiatric/neurological disorders are involved. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Although this is an fMRI study of Theory of Mind in healthy adults with whole-brain analyses reported, the participant age range is 24–64 years. The review’s inclusion criterion requires participants aged 18–60. Because the sample includes participants older than 60, the study does not meet the age eligibility requirement and must be excluded. All other criteria (healthy participants, social task, whole-brain results) are met, but any single unmet inclusion criterion warrants exclusion.

Although the study scanned healthy adult physicians (ages 25–37) with fMRI during a social (patient–physician) interaction task, and participants meet the age and health criteria, the neuroimaging results were analyzed and reported using predefined region-of-interest (ROI) analyses (5 mm spheres around empathy/compassion coordinates) with FWE correction performed within ROIs. The review’s inclusion criteria require whole-brain results and explicitly exclude ROI-only analyses. Therefore the study does not meet the required whole-brain reporting criterion and must be excluded.

Although this is an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adult participants (women aged 22–45) performing a passive viewing task of child/dog faces, the reported analyses were conducted using an a priori ROI approach with small-volume correction (SVC). The manuscript frames and presents results primarily within predefined ROIs and uses SVC thresholds; there are no reported whole-brain, whole-brain-corrected results. The review’s inclusion criteria require whole-brain results and explicitly exclude studies reporting only ROI analyses. Therefore this study does not meet the requirement for whole-brain results and should be excluded.

This study used whole-brain dual-fMRI hyperscanning while participants performed an interactive social task (cooperative, competitive, control rounds), satisfying ‘functional MRI during a social-related task’. Participants were healthy adults (38 individuals; mean age 22.44, SD 1.90), within the 18–60 range. Analyses were whole-brain (preprocessing, group-independent component analysis and ISC across whole-brain components), not ROI-restricted. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not report clinical or patient samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports an event-related whole-brain fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=14, mean age 29.4) who performed a social-related task (categorizing point-light displays as social interaction vs. non-social). Data were analyzed with whole-brain random-effects statistics (SPM2) and FDR-corrected results are reported for clusters across the brain (not ROI-only). Participants were healthy adults within the 18–60 range. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and does not report patient groups. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This fMRI study acquired whole-brain functional imaging while healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 19–32) performed a task involving reading a literary text and providing suspense ratings. The experimental manipulation and analyses explicitly probe social-cognitive processes (mentalizing/theory-of-mind) and predictive inference: reported activations include medial frontal cortex and temporo-parietal junction—key social cognition regions. Whole-brain GLM results are reported with cluster-level FWE correction (and a separate ROI analysis for the amygdala); the study is not an ROI-only report, nor a review/meta-analysis, and participants were healthy. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study of real-time mutual eye contact (a social interaction task) in healthy adult participants (mean age ~21.8; no neurologic/psychiatric history). Whole-brain EPI volumes covering cortex and cerebellum were acquired and whole-brain analyses were conducted (voxelwise GLM with cluster-level FWE correction, interbrain voxel-to-voxel synchronization, and seed-to-voxel gPPI evaluated across the whole brain). Results are not limited to ROI-only analyses, the sample is healthy adults within 18–60, and the manuscript is an original empirical fMRI study rather than a review. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Study reports whole-brain fMRI (SPM8, random-effects, cluster correction) in healthy adult participants (n=20, mean age 20.65) performing tasks that explicitly require situational inference and future-prediction. Although the paradigm is framed as event simulation, 41/96 stimulus sets depicted social situations and the explicit ES contrasts engage regions known for social cognition; the authors also performed separate social vs. non-social analyses. This meets the review objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria apply: results are whole-brain (not ROI-only), participants are healthy, and the paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review).

The study used functional MRI while participants viewed traffic-awareness campaign videos designed to elicit empathy (a social-related task). Participants were healthy adults (20 right-handed males, age range 20–28, mean 22.1), within the 18–60 range. The paper reports whole-brain random-effects analyses with family-wise error correction (p<0.05, FWE) and provides whole-brain cluster results (CV>NV contrast). Although ROI analyses were also performed, whole-brain results are reported and served as the basis for ROIs; participants had no psychiatric or neurological disorders. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (Ultimatum Game) in healthy adult volunteers (mean ages ~31, inclusion/exclusion criteria excluded psychiatric/neurological disorders), within the 18–60 age range. The study reports whole-brain analyses (random-effects GLM, conjunction and interaction contrasts, cluster- and voxel-level FDR-corrected results) with MNI coordinates and supplementary whole-brain tables, not limited to ROI-only findings. Although some ROI and PPI analyses are reported, whole-brain results are present and meet the review’s requirements. Not a review/meta-analysis and participants are healthy; therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=35, mean age 29) using a social-related task: encoding and short-term memory for faces with emotional expressions (angry/happy/neutral), which is social cognition. The imaging analysis used whole-brain, random-effects ANCOVA with FDR correction and reports whole-brain clusters and Talairach coordinates (not ROI-only results). Participants were healthy, within the 18–60 age range, and no patient groups were involved. The paper is an original fMRI experiment (not a review/meta-analysis). Although ROI beta extractions were performed for some follow-ups, primary inference and reported results derive from whole-brain analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports an event-related whole-brain fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (n=12, mean age 25.2) performing a social-related task (agency/intentionality attribution to animated agents). Imaging used whole-brain acquisition and SPM2 random-effects analyses with reported whole-brain activation maps (no ROI-only analysis). Participants were screened for neurological/psychiatric disorders (healthy sample). The study is an original empirical fMRI report (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria (fMRI during a social task, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=30, mean age 26) who performed a body-perception task involving self–other judgments (a social-cognitive/self-referential task). Imaging used whole-brain analyses (FSL FLAME mixed-effects, MNI registration, whole-brain cluster correction reported); results are not limited to ROI analyses. Participants were screened as healthy (no neurological/psychiatric disorders reported). The paper is an original empirical study (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of prosody perception and production tied to social communication and empathy (social-related processing). Participants were healthy adult native-English speakers aged 18–58 (within 18–60). The experiment used whole-brain fMRI acquisition and whole-brain random-effects analyses (FDR-corrected maps reported), with additional small-volume correction steps; primary results are whole-brain rather than ROI-only. The sample excludes neurological/psychiatric disorders and is not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

The study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (male, 18–24 y), meeting the age and health criteria. Participants completed an in-scanner behavioral task (listening to musical excerpts and rating aesthetic ‘beauty’), and the authors report whole-brain analyses (voxel-wise contrasts with cluster-level FDR correction) showing activation of default-mode/ToM and reward regions. The paper interprets these activations as engagement of cognitive empathy/social-cognition networks for artistic music, so it assesses social-related processing (implicit ToM/empathy). No exclusion criteria apply (not an ROI-only report, not a review, no clinical sample). Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion as an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a Face Matching Task (social/emotional face processing), which is a social-related task. Participants were healthy adults (n=10, mean age 25, within 18–60). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (first-level and second-level SPM whole-brain one-sample t-tests) and ICA whole-brain component maps (FDR-corrected spatial maps), not ROI-only results. No psychiatric or neurological patient groups were included. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI during social task, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a facial emotion discrimination task—an explicit social-related processing task. Participants are healthy adults aged 19–35 screened with the MINI to exclude psychiatric diagnoses (both excessive smartphone use and control groups are non-clinical). The paper presents whole-brain group comparisons with FWE-corrected cluster results (whole-brain analyses reported), not solely ROI analyses (ROIs are supplementary). It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, and does not report results from psychiatric or neurological patient samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (n=31; mean age 24.3, range within 18–60) that implements social-interaction tasks (take-advice game and trust game) during scanning to probe trust/honesty and social evaluation. Whole-brain analyses are reported throughout (whole-brain searchlight MVPA, univariate whole-brain contrasts with voxel-level p<0.001 and cluster FWE correction, PPI connectivity across the brain). Although a post-hoc OFC ROI is used for an additional analysis, primary results are whole-brain and not ROI-only. The sample is healthy and not clinical, and the article is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of theory-of-mind in healthy adult participants performing a social task, the reported analyses are ROI-based (MVPA within individually defined ToM and language ROIs). The paper does not present whole-brain voxelwise results; primary findings are restricted to region-of-interest classifications. The review’s exclusion criteria disallow studies that report only ROI analyses. Therefore the study should be excluded.

The study used fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=21, mean age 24) during tasks involving action observation and execution designed to probe mirror-system responses—processes widely considered part of social cognition (action understanding/mirroring). Participants completed active tasks in the scanner (shape observation, action observation, action execution). Whole-brain analyses are reported (p<0.001 uncorrected) in addition to ROI analyses, so results are not ROI-only. Participants were healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=21, mean age 24.6, within 18–60) that uses a social cognition task (forming impressions/trait inferences from bodies and names). Data were analyzed with whole-brain SPM8 GLMs and PPI connectivity analyses; results are reported as whole-brain contrasts (thresholds, clusters, FWE-corrected results) rather than ROI-only outcomes. Participants were screened for neurological damage and there is no clinical population. The study is empirical (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (fMRI during social task; healthy adults 18–60; whole-brain results) and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports fMRI data collected while participants performed a social-related task (Visual–Verbal Self-Other Referential Processing Task), involving self- vs other-referential processing—clearly social cognition. Participants were healthy adults aged 18–52 (within 18–60). Imaging used whole-brain acquisition and whole-brain analyses (SPM8 GLM), with cluster-wise whole-brain contrasts and tables of whole-brain results reported; although some ROI small-volume corrections are used, the primary results are whole-brain rather than ROI-only. This is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and excludes psychiatric/neurological disorders. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI experiment examining self- vs. other-referential social cognition (agentic vs. conceptual self-referential recollection) in healthy adult participants (N=18; age range 19–29). The study collected functional MRI data during performance of social-related tasks and reports whole-brain analyses (including whole-brain FWE-corrected results) in addition to ROI/SVC analyses for mPFC. Participants were healthy, within the 18–60 age range, and the paper is an original empirical study (not a review/meta-analysis) with no clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (task is social-related, fMRI during task, healthy adults, whole-brain results) and does not violate exclusion criteria (ROI analyses were performed but whole-brain results are reported).

This is an fMRI study of attentional orienting using social cues (eye gaze and voice) versus non-social cues (arrow and tone). Participants were healthy adults (N=22, mean age 22.95 yrs, right-handed, no neurological/psychiatric disorders). The methods report whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxel-wise FWE correction and whole-brain contrasts (with additional small-volume corrections for a priori ROIs), i.e. not ROI-only results. The task is social-related (gaze/voice contextual processing). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: study used functional MRI while participants completed a social-related task (the altruism/dictator-style task manipulating focus on Ethics/Partner), participants were healthy adults (mean age ~28, range within 18–60), and whole-brain analyses were reported (searchlight MVPA and whole-brain group-level tests with FWE cluster correction). Although supplementary ROI analyses were performed post-hoc, primary results and decoding maps derive from whole-brain searchlight analyses and are not limited to ROI-only results. No psychiatric/neurological populations were included. Therefore the study should be included.

This is an empirical fMRI study with healthy adult participants (final N=23; mean age 26.4, right-handed, neurologically healthy), using a task that probes social perception/action observation (viewing agents interacting with objects and rating smoothness/liking). Whole-brain analyses were performed and reported (voxel-wise thresholds, cluster correction; whole-brain contrasts for main effects and interactions are described). The study is not a review/meta-analysis, does not focus on clinical populations, and does not report only ROI results. All inclusion criteria (fMRI during social-related task, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results) are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study tested social processing: participants performed a gaze-based spatial stimulus-response task using anthropomorphic virtual characters (social gaze). Sample comprised healthy adults (N=30 after exclusions), ages 19–41 (within 18–60). The paper reports whole-brain voxelwise activation analyses (second-level flexible factorial, cluster-forming p<0.001 uncorrected and cluster FWE p<0.05) and whole-brain results for main effects and interactions. It is not an ROI-only report, not a review/meta-analysis, and participants did not have psychiatric or neurological disorders. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: 3T fMRI data were acquired during social tasks (dyadic eye-contact tasks A and B), involving healthy adult participants (19 pairs, ages 18–33; informed consent and IRB approved). Analyses report whole-brain preprocessing, group GLM and paired t-tests registered to MNI152, cluster results and atlas labels (CCRI masks), and group-level ICA projecting ICs onto whole-brain CCRI—i.e., whole-brain results rather than ROI-only analyses. Not a review/meta-analysis and no clinical/psychiatric sample. Although partial occipital signal loss is noted, the study reports whole-brain results and uses standard atlas labeling, so it satisfies the review’s requirements.

The study used fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 18–35) during a self-assessment task (rating whether an odour is one they would like to smell like), which is relevant to social/self-related processing. However, the reported neuroimaging results are based on ROI/small-volume analyses (seven pre-specified self-related ROIs) and the primary reported significant findings derive from these ROI-based comparisons. Although the authors state that whole-brain analyses were performed, the paper does not present whole-brain corrected results for the peptide contrasts, and the main reported effects are ROI-focused. This violates the inclusion criterion requiring whole-brain results and meets the exclusion criterion for studies reporting ROI-only results.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=31 analyzed; ages 18–35) that measured BOLD responses while participants viewed faces (pre- vs. post-surgical treatment) and performed a gender-judgment cover task. The study addresses social processing (perception of facial disfigurement, stigma, empathy/dehumanization). The fMRI analysis reports whole-brain group results using non-parametric SnPM with cluster-level FWE correction and also presents whole-brain statistical maps/clusters. No psychiatric/neurological patient groups were studied and the paper is an original empirical study (not a review) and not limited to ROI-only results. All inclusion criteria are met.

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants (fMRI group: 10 males aged 24–37) and investigates social-related processing (non-verbal facial/vocal cues, pSTS involvement), it does NOT provide whole-brain fMRI results. The acquisition used a 14-slice split-sagittal protocol optimized for STS/STG and explicitly states that medial regions, more medial aspects of frontal/parietal cortex, fusiform and early visual cortex were excluded from coverage. The review’s inclusion criteria require whole-brain results; this partial/targeted coverage violates that criterion. No other exclusion criteria (ROI-only analyses, patient groups, reviews) apply. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adults (mean age 25.6±5.6, within 18–60). The task is explicitly social: subjects learned and made inter-temporal choices for self and for other agents (human confederate and computer), examining social influence on preferences. Imaging analyses include whole-brain random-effects contrasts with cluster-level FWE correction reporting mPFC, pMFC, striatum, and visual cortex effects; results are not limited to ROI-only findings (although some ROI/jackknife follow-ups are used). It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and participants were neurologically and psychiatrically healthy. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

While this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (theory-of-mind and social attribution tasks; participants age 19–23), it does not provide whole-brain task activation results. The primary task analyses used localized probabilistic ICA applied within an ROI mask restricted to the temporoparietal region (TPJ), and task-related components were identified only within that ROI. This ROI-constrained approach means the main reported task activations are not whole-brain GLM results, effectively constituting an ROI-limited analysis. Although the paper reports seed-to-voxel connectivity maps across the brain, the central task activation findings are confined to the TPJ mask and thus fail the inclusion requirement for whole-brain results and fall under the exclusion of ROI-based analyses.

Although this fMRI study used healthy adult participants (ages 21–46) and reports whole-brain analyses in addition to ROI work, the experimental task centered on viewing erotic pictures and videos to probe sexual arousal and incentive motivation related to sexual orientation. The meta-analysis requires studies to involve a social-related task (e.g., social cognition, mentalizing, face/voice social evaluation). The present study’s primary objective and measures are sexual/affective processing of erotic stimuli rather than social cognitive processing per se. Therefore it does not meet the key inclusion criterion of an fMRI scan during a social-related task and should be excluded.

This study reports functional MRI data collected while healthy adult humans (final N=24; age 19–31) performed a social task involving cooperation and competition with others, satisfying the social-related task criterion. Participants were healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The manuscript reports whole-brain GLM analyses identifying regions such as pgACC and area 9 and discusses whole-brain findings; although ROI analyses were also performed, results are not ROI-only. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and does not involve psychiatric or neurological patient populations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports whole‑brain fMRI data collected while healthy adult participants (N=30; age 19–39) completed social-related tasks: viewing a movie depicting a moral dilemma between sisters (inter-subject correlation whole-brain analysis) and a separate in-scanner moral-decision task analyzed with whole-brain GLM. Results are reported across the whole brain (ISC and GLM maps), not restricted to ROIs. Participants were healthy, within the 18–60 age range. The paper is an original fMRI research article (not a review) and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=19 males, age range 18–51) performing an emotional prosody comprehension task that includes complex/social emotions (e.g., proud, guilty) — a social-related processing task. Imaging analysis used whole-brain SPM8 with cluster-level correction across the whole brain (not ROI-only) and reports whole-brain results. Participants were healthy (no psychiatric/neurological disorders reported). The paper is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review/meta-analysis. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) fMRI during a social-related task — a task comparing anticipation of touching an animate (human hand) versus inanimate (mannequin) target; (2) healthy adult participants aged 21–33 (N=32; task data N=21), within 18–60; (3) whole-brain voxel-wise analyses reported (paired-sample t-tests and voxel-wise covariate analyses with FDR correction). Does not violate exclusion criteria: not an ROI-only paper (whole-brain results are primary), not a review/meta-analysis, and participants had no reported psychiatric/neurological disorders. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the review.

While this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.8) with an appropriate social task (judging facing-toward vs away; mirror and mentalizing system engagement), the primary statistical inference was conducted using a priori anatomical masks for the Mirror Neuron System and Mentalizing System. The authors state that the ANOVAs and post-hoc tests were performed within these two masks (“adopted as searching areas”), and reported results are restricted to those masked regions (small-volume/ROI-based inference). The review’s eligibility requires whole-brain results and excludes ROI-only analyses. Because the reported analyses are region-masked rather than unbiased whole-brain inference, the study does not meet the ‘whole-brain results’ inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Although this is an fMRI study of social evaluation in healthy adults (N=36, mean age 22) performing a social-related task, the neuroimaging results are reported based on a small-volume/ROI analysis focused on bilateral posterior vACC (small volume correction within an 870-voxel ROI). The inclusion criteria require whole-brain results and the exclusion criteria disallow ROI-only analyses. While preprocessing and group modeling were whole-brain, statistical inference and reported effects relied on the vACC ROI/SVC rather than whole-brain corrected results, so the study does not meet the whole-brain reporting requirement and therefore must be excluded.

This is an original fMRI study using an empathy-for-pain paradigm (viewing images of others in pain) — a social-related task — acquired in healthy adult participants (male, aged 18–40). The paper reports whole-brain analyses (family-wise error correction, whole-brain results and conjunction analyses) in addition to ROI analyses, and presents whole-brain findings linking stress to activation in empathy-related regions. No clinical/psychiatric sample, and this is not a review/meta-analysis. All inclusion criteria (fMRI during social task, healthy adults within 18–60, whole-brain results) are met; none of the exclusion criteria are violated (ROI analyses were performed but whole-brain results are reported). Therefore the study should be included.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it reports an fMRI experiment in which healthy adult participants (N=20; ages 18–29) performed a social task (forced-choice social evaluations of target persons across situations). Whole-brain analyses are reported (multilevel whole-brain MLM with voxelwise results and cluster thresholds), with ROI follow-ups but not limited to ROI-only reporting. Participants are healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review or meta-analysis) and does not report data from clinical populations. Therefore it should be included in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study reports whole-brain fMRI results (group-level mixed-effects analyses) in a healthy adult sample (n=51, ages 18–42) who performed a face-processing task. Face perception is a social-related task, and adults fall within the 18–60 range. The paper is not a review/meta-analysis and does not involve participants with psychiatric or neurological disorders. Although the study also includes children, it presents adult whole-brain results (and adult-only analyses used for ROI definition), so it is appropriate for inclusion in a meta-analysis of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. The fact that the paper additionally conducts ROI analyses does not exclude it, because whole-brain results are provided.

While this fMRI study used healthy adult participants (ages ~22) and examined social processing (passive viewing of dynamic facial expressions), the reported statistical analyses and results are based primarily on region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with small-volume corrections (WFU PickAtlas masks). The paper does not report whole-brain, voxel-wise corrected results independent of ROI/SVC; inclusion requires whole-brain results. Because the study effectively provides ROI-only findings, it meets the exclusion criterion (ROI analyses) and therefore should be excluded from the review.

This study used task-based fMRI during social-cognitive processing (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM) in a sample of healthy adult participants (no history of mental/neurological disorders). Whole-brain analyses were conducted and reported (FWE-corrected threshold reported), along with ROI analyses; however, whole-brain results are present (not ROI-only). It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and does not include clinical/psychiatric samples. Although exact participant ages are not explicitly listed in the excerpt, the sample comprises healthy undergraduates/adults, consistent with the 18–60 criterion. Therefore it meets the review inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (15 right-handed male participants, mean age 23.6) that used whole-brain GLM analyses to examine neural responses while participants observed social interactions (violent dyadic interactions) — a social-related task. The paper reports whole-brain results (e.g., amygdala, insula, ACC, EBA, STS) with cluster-size correction and functional connectivity across the brain, not limited to ROI-only findings (though localizers/ROIs were also used for comparison). Participants are healthy and within the 18–60 age range. The study is original empirical research (not a review) and does not involve clinical or psychiatric samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used fMRI while healthy adult participants (final sample N=34, ages 20–30) performed a social cognition task (a modified Empathic Accuracy Task assessing empathy/mentalising). Analyses were whole-brain (SPM12 preprocessing, group-level random-effects, TFCE FWE correction) with reported whole-brain clusters and peak activations; no ROI-only reporting. Participants with psychiatric/neurological disorders were excluded. The paper is an original fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and reports results suitable for inclusion in a meta-analysis of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception, cooperation/deception) with healthy adult participants (n=13; age range 22–38, within 18–60). The task required participants to attribute intentions/beliefs while being scanned. The paper reports exploratory whole-brain random-effects analyses (ToM vs non-ToM) and contrasts between conditions with whole-brain results (thresholds and cluster extent provided), although ROI-based follow-up was also performed. Participants had no neurological or psychiatric disorders. This is an original experimental fMRI study (not a review) and does not report data from clinical populations. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (ages 18–55) performing a social-related task (imitate/observe emotional faces). Participants were screened healthy (SCID, urine tox) and no psychiatric/neurological disorders included. Whole-brain analyses were performed (spatio-temporal PLS across the whole brain with voxel-wise bootstrap ratios and a corroborating whole-brain GLM in SPM8; results presented as whole-brain voxel patterns in MNI space). Not a review/meta-analysis, and not an ROI-only study. All inclusion criteria met and no exclusion criteria violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 22) performing a social-related task (viewing eyes and dynamic pupillary feedback to examine social salience). Whole-brain fMRI data were acquired and whole-brain group analyses are reported (main effect of viewing eye stimuli reported at whole-brain corrected threshold), not ROI-only results. Participants were screened for neurological/psychiatric illness and none were reported. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: The study reports a task-based functional MRI experiment where healthy adult participants (N=22; mean age 27.35, all native speakers; no neurological/psychiatric history) performed a social-related task (classification of speakers’ communicative intentions from prosody). Whole-brain analyses are reported (voxel-level threshold P<0.0001 with cluster-level FWE correction P<0.05) rather than ROI-only results. The sample falls within the 18–60 age range and participants were screened for neurological/psychiatric disorders. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it should be included in the review of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=60 male participants, mean age 23.8, within 18–60) who performed an explicit social task (impression formation of faces varying in race and socioeconomic status) while being scanned. The paper reports whole-brain analyses (behavioral and task PLS across the whole brain with voxelwise bootstrap ratios and cluster reporting) rather than ROI-only results. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and does not report data from psychiatric or neurological patient groups. All inclusion criteria are met (task-based fMRI, healthy adults 18–60, whole-brain results); no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=27; ages ~24.9–26.3) that examined neural processing of social interactions while participants viewed pictures of cooperative and affective interactions (a social-related task). Imaging used whole-brain analyses (random-effects, whole-brain contrasts, conjunctions) with FWE-corrected thresholds reported; thus whole-brain results are available. Although ROI analyses are also reported, results are not ROI-only. Participants were healthy and within the 18–60 age range, and this is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). No exclusion criteria (clinical samples, ROI-only results, or review) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This paper reports two original fMRI experiments in healthy adult participants (study 1 n=41, study 2 n=39; ages 18–24; screened for psychiatric/neurological disorders). Tasks probe social-related processing (sharing decisions, mentalizing-related constructs; a social-processing ROI based on a false-belief localizer) while participants viewed article headlines/abstracts. The authors report both ROI analyses and exploratory whole-brain analyses (cluster- and permutation-corrected whole-brain maps and tables of clusters associated with population-level virality), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain results. This is not a review/meta-analysis and does not involve clinical populations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used task-based fMRI while participants performed a social decision-making task (control aversion task involving choices influenced by another person), meeting the social-related task requirement. Participants were healthy young adults (n=51 after exclusions, mean age 22, screened for psychiatric/neurological disorders), meeting the healthy 18–60 criterion. Analyses were whole-brain (random-effects, whole-brain cluster-level FWE correction reported) and results are not limited to ROI-only approaches. The paper is original empirical fMRI research (not a review) and does not include clinical patients. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=18; ages 18–30) performing a social-related task (gaze perception/mentalizing). The authors report whole-brain second-level analyses (AQ regressor) with whole-brain FDR-corrected results (p<0.05) identifying clusters in pSTS, TPJ, amygdala, IPS, etc. Participants with neurological/psychiatric disorders were excluded. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Although supplementary ROI analyses are reported, the primary inferential statistics reported are whole-brain analyses, so the study meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it used functional MRI while participants (healthy, nulliparous adults ages 19–29) completed social-related tasks (viewing infant faces of varying affect and listening to infant cries), and participants were screened as healthy with no psychiatric/neurological disorders. The paper reports whole-brain, random-effects analyses with family-wise error correction and cluster thresholds (i.e., not limited to ROI analyses). It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis) and the participant age range falls within 18–60. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult humans (male students mean age 21.35) performing an approach-avoidance task that explicitly contrasts social vs nonsocial stimuli, addressing social-related processing. Participants are within the 18–60 range and screened as healthy; no psychiatric/neurological disorders reported. Although ROI analyses were a priori used, the methods state and the results refer to additional exploratory whole-brain analyses (thresholded and reported), so whole-brain results are available rather than ROI-only reporting. The paper is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review/meta-analysis). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This paper reports original fMRI data in healthy adult participants (three separate studies, total n=59) performing social-related tasks (person knowledge: faces/names; socially relevant concept words). Imaging used whole-brain acquisition and analyses (whole-brain contrasts social > non-social reported, with cluster thresholds detailed) alongside ROI analyses. Participants are described as healthy control adults and data are not from psychiatric/neurologic patient groups (though a larger study included TLE patients, only control data are used here). The study is not a review/meta-analysis. Although exact participant ages were not listed in the provided excerpt, the sample is described as control adults in typical fMRI experiments; overall, all inclusion criteria are met (functional MRI during social tasks, healthy participants, whole-brain results).

Although the study uses fMRI with a social face-processing task in healthy young adults (age ~20s), the functional analyses are ROI-based: BOLD time series were extracted from 25 predefined face-related ROIs and analyses used interregional correlation matrices and structural covariance at the group level. The paper does not report whole-brain, voxelwise fMRI results — analyses and reported outcomes are confined to predefined ROIs and group-level covariance. Per exclusion criteria (studies reporting ROI-only analyses), this study must be excluded.

execution_stats.search_query: ( ('functional MRI'[Title/Abstract] OR 'functional magnetic resonance imaging'[Title/Abstract] OR 'fMRI'[Title/Abstract] ) AND ( 'social communication'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social processing'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social interaction'[Title/Abstract] OR 'affiliation'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social attachment'[Title/Abstract] OR 'social cognition'[Title/Abstract] OR 'understanding others'[Title/Abstract] ) AND 'Humans'[MeSH])
